If you '''inherit an IRA''' (Individual Retirement Arrangement), you are called a beneficiary. A beneficiary can be any person or entity the owner chooses to receive the benefits of the IRA after they die. Beneficiaries of a traditional IRA must include in their gross income any taxable distributions they receive.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=Internal Revenue Service|title=Topic no. 451, Individual retirement arrangements (IRAs)|url=https://www.irs.gov/taxtopics/tc451}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
IRAs can be held at a bank or other financial institution or with a mutual fund or life insurance company.<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590a| title=Publication 590-A (2023), Contributions to Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)| publisher=Internal Revenue Service| accessdate=April 25, 2024}}</ref>
In almost all cases, it is advantageous to name the primary and contingent beneficiaries you wish to inherit your IRA, as opposed to not naming beneficiaries and having the IRA go through will/estate/probate.
You can also choose not to inherit the IRA; known as "disclaiming" the assets. This may be useful if you want the benefits to go to someone else, or do not want to pay taxes on the assets.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.investopedia.com/articles/retirement/03/041603.asp| title=Disclaiming Inherited Plan Assets| publisher=Investopedia| date=June 14, 2022| accessdate=April 25, 2024}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|If you decide to disclaim in full or partial, taking the year of death RMD does not constitute acceptance of the IRA, so you can still take the year of death RMD and then disclaim. This is LIMITED to the year of death RMD, and there are still other formal requirements for a qualified disclaimer. You do not all have to disclaim, or disclaim the same amount, but future equitable accounting may become complicated if any of you diverge.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://easysite.commonwealth.com/EasySites/EasySite_T9193Y/_uploads/How%20and%20Why%20to%20Disclaim%20an%20IRA.pdf| title=How and Why to Disclaim an IRA.pdf| url-status=dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306045952/http://easysite.commonwealth.com/EasySites/EasySite_T9193Y/_uploads/How%20and%20Why%20to%20Disclaim%20an%20IRA.pdf| archive-date=March 6, 2016}}</ref> However, doing it this way can be complicated. It is simpler to do the disclaimer first, and then for the beneficiaries (determined after the disclaimer) to set up separate inherited IRAs and take the distributions pro rata.<ref>{{forum link| p=2064911| title=Inherited IRA decision}}</ref>|group="note"}}
==Types of IRA beneficiaries==
The Secure Act modified the RMD rules for certain beneficiaries of inherited IRAs. IRA beneficiaries post Secure Act can now be classified into three categories:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.investopedia.com/not-designated-beneficiary-definition-5025735| title=Not Designated Beneficiaries|publisher=Investopedia}}</ref>
1. Eligible Designated Beneficiaries (EDB). There are specific requirements to qualify for EDB status, which entitles the individual beneficiaries to a lifetime stretch, similar to prior to the SECURE act.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.morningstar.com/retirement/ed-slott-how-eligible-designated-beneficiaries-changed|title=How Rules on Eligible Designated Beneficiaries Changed for Inherited IRAs| author1=Christine Benz| author2=Ed Slott |publisher=Morningstar|date=May 9, 2024}}</ref> The beneficiaries must be individuals or “see through” trusts in which the trust’s individual beneficiary qualifies as an EDB.
The following are considered eligible designated beneficiaries and still qualify for a lifetime stretch:
*The owner’s surviving spouse *The owner’s child who is less than 21 years of age<ref>{{cite web| url=https://irahelp.com/slottreport/age-majority-and-new-secure-act-regulations/#:~:text=The%20age%20of%20majority%20is,required%20minimum%20distribution%20(RMD).| title=AGE OF MAJORITY AND THE NEW SECURE ACT REGULATION| author1=Andy Ives| author2=Ed Slott | publisher=The Slott Report|date=March 2, 2022}}</ref><ref group="note">The child is allowed to stretch IRA payments until they are 21. At that time, the 10-year payout rule will apply, and the now-adult child will have another 10 years to maintain the inherited IRA. </ref> *A disabled individual *A chronically ill individual<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.wealthmanagement.com/estate-planning/special-needs-trusts-can-help-secure-stretch-ira| title=Special Needs Trusts Can Help SECURE a 'Stretch' IRA| author1=Robert Dietz | author2=Jennifer Goode | publisher=Wealth Management|date=April 20, 2023}}</ref> *Any other individual who is not more than 10 years younger than the deceased IRA owner<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.kitces.com/blog/secure-act-stretch-ira-401k-elimination-eligible-designated-beneficiary-retirement-accounts-taxes/| title=The (Partial) Death Of The Stretch IRA: How The SECURE Act Impacts Inherited Retirement Accounts| author=Michael Kitces| date=February 12, 2020}}</ref>
2. Non-Eligible Designated Beneficiaries - this category now must liquidate IRA holdings within a 10 year period (the 10 year rule). Many designated beneficiaries were formerly eligible for a lifetime stretch. These beneficiaries are typically all other individuals who are not EDBs (including “see through” trusts where the individual beneficiary if the trust falls into this category).
3. Not/Non Designated Beneficiaries - These include beneficiaries that are entities and not persons, such as an estate, a non see through trust and charities. These are subject to different rules, one of which could include distribution from the IRA over a 5 year period.{{#tag:ref| If the estate remains the IRA beneficiary, the IRA must be distributed according to the following rules: *If the IRA owner has started taking required minimum distributions, the IRA must be distributed at least as quickly as the decedent's remaining required minimum distributions. * If the IRA owner is not taking required minimum distributions the IRA must be distributed according to the five-year rule. Under the five-year rule, the assets must be distributed by December 31 of the fifth year since the retirement account owner's death.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=89-90}}<ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.schwab.com/learn/story/inheriting-ira-understand-your-options | title= Inheriting an IRA? Understand Your Choices | author=Hayden Adams| publisher=Schwab|date=May 1, 2024}}</ref> |group="note"}} A [[Charitable remainder trust]] is an exception to this and can be an advantageous way to leave traditional IRA assets mostly to an individual with a remainder to charity.
==IRA inherited from your spouse== {{Quote |quote = '''<u>Spousal Inheritance of an IRA'''</u> You will only be considered to have chosen to treat the IRA as your own if: * You are the sole beneficiary of the IRA, and * You have an unlimited right to withdraw amounts from it.<ref>{{cite book| author=Natalie Choate| title=Life and Death Planning for Retirement Benefits| edition=6th| date=2006| isbn=978-0-9649440-7-7| p=169| ref={{SfnRef|Choate|2006}}}}</ref>
You will be considered to have chosen to treat the IRA as your own if: * Contributions (including rollover contributions) are made to the inherited IRA, or * You do not take the required minimum distribution for a year as a beneficiary of the IRA.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=170}}}} If you inherit a traditional IRA from your spouse, you generally have the following three choices. You can: :1. Treat it as your own IRA by designating yourself as the account owner. :2. Treat it as your own by rolling it over into your traditional IRA, or to the extent it is taxable, into a: :* Qualified employer plan, :* Qualified employee annuity plan (section 403(a) plan), :* Tax-sheltered annuity plan (section 403(b) plan), :* Deferred compensation plan of a state or local government (section 457 plan), or :3. Treat yourself as the beneficiary rather than treating the IRA as your own.<ref name="590B">{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b| title=Publication 590-B (2023), Distributions from Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs)| publisher=IRS| accessdate=April 25, 2024}} (What if You Inherit an IRA?)</ref>
There are a number of clear advantages to spousal rollovers of an IRA. *By using a spousal rollover, the surviving spouse can use their own age and Uniform Lifetime Table based life expectancy for starting Required Minimum Distributions from the IRA. Often this can mean a longer period for tax deferral of the IRA.{{#tag:ref|In the first year of ownership, you must take the deceased owner's [[Required Minimum Distribution vs annuitization | RMD]] for that year (to the extent it was not already distributed to the owner before their death).<ref name="590B" />|group="note"}} *With a spousal rollover, the surviving spouse can use the IRS Uniform Lifetime Table, which is based upon the combined life expectancy of the owner and someone ten years younger, rather than the typically less favorable Single Life table. The uniform tables provide for a slower payout of required minimum distributions. *A spousal rollover allows a surviving spouse to name primary and contingent beneficiaries to the IRA. This allows the surviving spouse, if the situation warrants, to correct any problems in the original beneficiary designations. These beneficiaries will follow current IRS rules, typically requiring full distribution within 10 years unless they qualify as Eligible Designated Beneficiaries. * If the spouse opts to inherit the IRA rather than executing a rollover, the distribution of the IRA will be distributed over the Single Life Table life expectancy of the spouse if the owner died before the RBD (currently 73). If the owner died after the RBD, the spouse uses the longer of their own Single Life Table or the deceased owner's remaining life expectancy." * As of 2024, final regulations were issued surrounding the Secure Act 2.0, and an additional option was created for spouses. Spouses can choose to inherit the IRA, but instead use the more favorable uniform lifetime RMD table, instead of the less favorable single lifetime table.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.kitces.com/blog/rmd-spousal-election-secure-2-0-secure-act-rmd-rules-spousal-beneficiaries-retirement-account/| title=New RMD Rules For Spousal Beneficiaries Of Retirement Accounts With SECURE 2.0’s “Spousal Election” Option| publisher=Kitces.com| accessdate=October 24, 2025}}</ref>
A spouse might decide to forgo a spousal rollover if they are under the age of 59 1/2 and have a clear need for the income from the IRA. Before the 2024 final regulations, as beneficiary, the surviving spouse was required to take minimum distributions based on the Single Life Table from the account. Withdrawals would be exempt from the 10% early withdrawal penalty tax.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=164-165}} After the 2024 updated regulations, the spousal beneficiary can choose use to use the more favorable uniform lifetime table.
If you do not explicitly act to make an election (that is, you do not retitle the account and do not take an RMD as required), it defaults to "treat IRA as your own."
==IRA inherited from someone other than your spouse== If you inherit a traditional IRA from anyone other than your deceased spouse, you cannot treat the inherited IRA as your own. This means that you cannot make any contributions to the IRA. It also means you cannot roll over any amounts into or out of the inherited IRA. However, you can make a trustee-to-trustee transfer as long as the IRA into which amounts are being moved is set up and maintained in the name of the deceased IRA owner for the benefit of you as beneficiary.<ref name="590B" />
Like the original owner, you generally will not owe tax on the assets in the IRA until you receive distributions from it. With the passage of the SECURE Act, IRA distributions to a non-spouse must be completed within 10 years following the death of the account owner, unless the beneficiary qualifies as an “eligible designated beneficiary” in which case the beneficiary still qualifies for a lifetime stretch. As of July 2024, the IRS issued final regulations that confirm RMDS are required for years 1-9 for those IRAs subject to the 10 year rule. However this will be enforced starting in 2025, and RMDS not taken from 2021-2024 will be forgiven (including penalties).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://public-inspection.federalregister.gov/2024-14542.pdf| title=Required Minimum Distributions| publisher=Internal Revenue Service|date=July 17, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.wsj.com/personal-finance/retirement/ira-inheritance-rules-minimum-withdrawals-671b7952?mod=hp_lead_pos11| title=Heirs Finally Get an Answer From IRS About Money in Inherited Retirement Accounts| author= Ashlea Ebeling| publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=July 18, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.morningstar.com/financial-advisors/irs-finalizes-rmd-regulations-key-takeaways-10-year-rule-beneficiaries | title= IRS Finalizes RMD Regulations: Key Takeaways and the 10-Year Rule for Beneficiaries | author=Denise Applebee| publisher=Morningstar|date=July 22, 2024}}</ref><ref name="Levine">{{cite web| url= https://www.kitces.com/blog/secure-act-2-0-irs-regulations-rmd-required-minimum-distributions-10-year-rule-eligible-designated-beneficiary-see-through-conduit-trust/| title= Untangling The IRS’s New Finalized (And Proposed) Regulations On RMDs: The 10-Year Rule, Trust Beneficiaries, Spousal Beneficiaries, Annuities, And More!| author=Jeff Levine| publisher=Kitces.com|date=July 24, 2024}}</ref>{{#tag:ref| In 2022, the IRS issued proposed regulations saying that, in addition to the 10-year rule, beneficiaries of IRA owners who died after their required beginning date would have to take RMDs in years 1 through 9. Due to confusion and controversy surrounding the proposed regulations, the IRS subsequently waived the penalty for not taking RMDs year 1-9 in tax years 2021-2023<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.morningstar.com/retirement/faqs-about-inherited-iras | title=Be Aware of These New Rules for Inherited IRAs| author=Christine Benz| publisher=Morningstar|date=March 20, 2024}}</ref> and 2024.<ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.morningstar.com/personal-finance/irs-extends-waiver-excise-tax-inherited-iras-not-rmds| title=IRS Extends Waiver of Excise Tax for Inherited IRAs, but Not RMDs| author=Denise Appleby| publisher=Morningstar|date=April 24, 2024}}</ref><ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-drop/n-24-35.pdf| title= Notice 2024-35-Certain Required Minimum Distributions for 2024| publisher=Internal Revenue Service|date=April 24, 2024}}</ref> Finally, as of July 2024, the IRS issued final regulations that confirm RMDS are required for years 1-9 for those IRAs subject to the 10 year rule. However this will be enforced starting in 2025, and RMDS not taken from 2021-2024 will be forgiven (including penalties).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://public-inspection.federalregister.gov/2024-14542.pdf| title=Required Minimum Distributions| publisher=Internal Revenue Service|date=July 17, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.morningstar.com/financial-advisors/irs-finalizes-rmd-regulations-key-takeaways-10-year-rule-beneficiaries| title= IRS Finalizes RMD Regulations: Key Takeaways and the 10-Year Rule for Beneficiaries | author=Denise Applebee| publisher=Morningstar|date=July 22, 2024}}</ref><ref name="Levine" />|group="note"}}{{#tag:ref|The Single Life Table is used to calculate RMDs for your beneficiaries, but only if they are an “eligible designated beneficiary.” This table is also used if you die after your “required beginning date” (April 1 after your age 73 year) without naming a living beneficiary. The IRS regulations include a special “reset” provision for calculating RMDs for non-spouse beneficiaries who inherit before January 1, 2022.<ref>{{cite web| title=Inheriting IRAs from someone other than your spouse| url=https://www.fidelity.com/learning-center/personal-finance/retirement/non-spouse-IRA| date=February 25, 2020| publisher=Fidelity Viewpoints| accessdate=December 9, 2020| url-status=dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240118201112/https://www.fidelity.com/learning-center/personal-finance/retirement/non-spouse-IRA| archive-date=January 18, 2024}}</ref>|group="note"}}
The proposed year 1-9 RMD regulations do not apply to inherited Roth IRAs, in which case all monies merely have to be distributed by the end of year 10. Executors have until December 31 of the year following the death of the decedent owner to properly title and distribute the IRA to the beneficiaries. Multiple beneficiaries should split the IRA into separate interests so that each beneficiary can: *Select a fiduciary of choice for investing the inherited IRA; *Execute their own individual investment plan and account succession.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=91-95}}
If an IRA having multiple beneficiaries is not split into separate accounts, the required minimum distribution is based on the life expectancy factor for the oldest beneficiary.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=90}}
If you establish multiple inherited IRAs you can make tax-free transfers between the inherited IRAs. Although the RMD must be figured on each individual inherited IRA, the RMD can be taken from any of the IRAs.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=73}}
If you inherit IRAs from more than one individual, you cannot commingle or aggregate the inherited IRAs. Transfers between IRAs and RMD calculations must be made within each group of inherited IRAs.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=90}}
An inheritor of an IRA can, and should, name primary and contingent beneficiaries to the inherited IRA. The inherited IRA will always retain the required minimum distribution schedule for the original inheritor.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=95}}
For IRAs inherited by designated beneficiaries and paid out under the 10-year rule, consider tax management when determining the RMD schedule. It is rarely a good idea to wait until the 10th year to withdraw the entire balance, or take RMDs on your own life expectancy for years 1-9.
==IRA inherited by the estate==
If you do not name beneficiaries to the IRA, the IRA will be inherited by your estate and will be distributed to the beneficiaries established by will or intestacy law. An estate executor can still designate an inherited IRA to the beneficiaries, as long as this is completed by December 31 of the year following the decedent's death. Estate executors can use a [http://www.ataxplan.com/bulletinBoard/pdfs/FiducLetterWebVersion.pdf sample letter] to properly execute the transfer of the inherited IRA to beneficiaries.
If the estate remains the IRA beneficiary, the IRA must be distributed according to the following rules: *If the IRA owner has started taking required minimum distributions, the IRA must be distributed at least as quickly as the decedent's remaining required minimum distributions. * If the IRA owner is not taking required minimum distributions the IRA must be distributed according to the five-year rule. Under the five-year rule, the assets must be distributed by December 31 of the fifth year since the retirement account owner's death.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=89-90}} * If the IRA left to the estate is directed to the spouse, the spouse may be able to rollover the inherited IRA to her own IRA, in certain cases.<ref name=":1" />
==IRA inherited by a charity==
Because a [[Traditional IRA]] contains a tax liability to the government, it is an attractive account for making a charitable contribution for people wanting to leave charitable bequests. And because a charity pays no income tax on its received gifts, and the testamentary contribution is an Estate Tax deduction, making a full or partial beneficial gift of an IRA balance is often reasonable, especially if the remaining estate is in a taxable account, receiving step-up valuation at death, or is in tax-free [[Roth IRA|Roth IRA accounts]]. It is often a good idea to keep planned charitable IRA contributions in a separate IRA. Using separate IRAs is the safest route as it ensures that individual beneficiaries can use lifetime required minimum distribution of the inherited IRA. A fractional beneficiary designation that includes both individual and charitable beneficiaries can be split by distribution of the charitable interest by September 30 of the year following the death of the IRA owner, or by the establishment of separate accounts by December 31 of the year following the IRA owner's death and allow individual lifetime distribution, but only if the the deadlines are met.{{sfn|Choate|2006|pp=357-359}}
==Advanced beneficiary options== These beneficiary options require the services of a qualified estate planner.
*Naming a [[Trusts#Inherited IRA trusts|trust as an IRA beneficiary]];{{#tag:ref|Trusts can be named as beneficiaries of IRAs/retirement accounts, but special care is needed to make sure the trust is set up and worded correctly and also that the particular trust beneficiaries meet the applicable criteria, such as being individuals (not entities) and meeting “look through” criteria. Failure to comply with these rules may cause the trust to lose its potential 10 year (non-EDB) or lifetime (EDB) stretch distribution status, and revert to the default 5 year distribution status applicable to most entities (non-individuals). It is advisable to seek out an estate planning attorney who is experienced with setting up trusts that ultimately will hold IRAs and/or other retirement accounts.<ref>{{cite web| url= https://ataxplan.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/Estate_Planning_for_Retirement_Benefits_post_SECURE_and_Prop_Regs.pdf | title= Estate Planning for Retirement Benefits Under SECURE and Proposed Treasury Regulations | p=67-75| author=Natalie Choate| publisher=Ataxplan|date=September 8, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.ntsa-net.org/industry-intel/marketbeat/naming-your-trust-beneficiary-ira| title= Naming Your Trust as Beneficiary of an IRA| author=NTSA| publisher=National Tax Deferred Association}}</ref>|group="note"}}{{#tag:ref|Leaving an IRA to someone else’s revocable living trust can sometimes be problematic and may reduce the applicable stretch. If the beneficiary is ultimately the spouse, the inherited IRA may be able to be rolled over to a spouse’s own IRA in certain circumstances.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://irahelp.com/irs-allows-spouses-roll-inherited-iras-through-own-trusts-their-iras/| title=IRS Allows Spouses to Roll Inherited IRAs Through Own Trusts to Their IRAs| publisher=Ed Slott and Company, LLC| date=September 8, 2014| accessdate=October 24, 2025}}</ref>|group="note"}} *Disclaiming an IRA; *Naming a [[Charitable remainder trust]], [[Donor advised fund]], or [[Charitable gift annuity]], as an IRA beneficiary.
==Deadlines==
Here are key dates you should keep in mind to make sure you meet the IRS deadlines that apply to the options you choose.
* December 31 of the original account owner's year of death. Prior to revised final IRS regulations on July 19, 2024, if the account owner died on or after their required beginning date (RBD), the RMD for the year must be satisfied if it was not taken in full during the account owner's lifetime. The July 2024 regulations extended the deadline to the later of the beneficiary’s year-of-death tax return deadline—generally April 15, including extensions—or December 31 of the year following the year of death. For most beneficiaries it will likely be the latter.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Rahn|first=Mike|date=December 19, 2024|title=RMD Regulations’ Year-of-Death Rules Yield Both Answers and Questions|url=https://thelink.ascensus.com/articles/2024/12/18/rmd-regulations-year-of-death-rules-yield-both-answers-and-questions|website=Ascensus}}</ref> * December 31 of the year following the original account owner's year of death. If you are taking RMD based on the life-expectancy method, distributions must begin by this date. If you are one of multiple beneficiaries, all beneficiaries must have established separate inherited IRA accounts by this date in order to calculate distributions based upon each beneficiary's own life expectancy. * September 30 of the year following the original account owner's year of death. Important for determining the beneficiary whose life expectancy may be used to calculate RMD (the designated beneficiary). If you are one of multiple beneficiaries of varying ages, all beneficiaries must use the life expectancy factor of the oldest beneficiary who has not taken a lump-sum distribution or disclaimed their entire interest prior to this date. However, if all of the beneficiaries have established separate IRA accounts by December 31 of the year following the account owner's death, then all beneficiaries may be able to use their own life expectancy factors to calculate their RMD. Check with your tax advisor to see if you are eligible for this benefit. * October 31 of the year following the account owner's year of death. Important if you are the trustee of a trust named as IRA beneficiary. The IRS mandates that trustees provide the fiduciary with a copy of the trust document or a summary list of the trust's beneficiaries and conditions by this date. If this requirement is not met, or if the trust failed to meet certain other IRS requirements, it is not considered a qualifying trust eligible for more favorable RMD calculations, usually based on the life-expectancy of the oldest trust beneficiary. * Within nine months after the original account owner's death. If you are planning to disclaim the assets, your written disclaimer generally must be received no later than nine months after the date on which you become entitled to the assets, according to IRS regulations.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://personal.vanguard.com/us/accounttypes/retirement/ATSIRAInheritDeadlinesNSContent.jsp| title=IRA Inheriting Deadlines| publisher=Vanguard}}{{dead link}}</ref>
==Federal estate tax deduction== {{Quote |quote = '''<u>Federal Estate Tax on Income in Respect of a Decedent'''.</u> "This is becoming an increasingly important deduction as more and more taxpayers inherit money in company retirement plans or traditional IRAs. Such amounts are considered "income in respect of a decedent" because the decedent had a right to the income at the time of death, but the income is not included on the person's final tax return. Instead, the beneficiary is taxed on the amounts. You might also deserve a deduction, though, if the decedent's estate was large enough to pay federal estate taxes. Say, for example, that you inherit a $50,000 IRA which, because it was included in your mother's taxable estate, boosted the estate tax bill by $20,500. Although you have to pay tax as you pull money out of the IRA, you also get a deduction for that $20,500. If you pull the full $50,000 out at once, you'd get the full deduction. If you pull it out equally over two years, you'd deduct $10,250 each year. This miscellaneous deduction is not subject to the 2% limit but it is up to you to know the rules to take advantage of them." |source = -- ''[http://turbotax.intuit.com/tax-tools/maximize_tax_deductions/article Tax Tips From TurboTax]''{{dead link}} }} A beneficiary may be able to claim a deduction for estate tax resulting from certain distributions from a traditional IRA. The beneficiary can deduct the estate tax paid on any part of a distribution that is [[Income in respect of a decedent|income in respect of a decedent]] (IRD). They can take the deduction for the tax year the income is reported. The deduction is taken by the beneficiary receiving the IRD, not the beneficiary who pays the estate tax.
{| class="wikitable" | <u>Example</u><br> Jack dies in 2002 with an estate of $3 million. He leaves his $1 million IRA (which is entirely IRD) to his daughters Jill and Holly. He leaves his $2 million probate estate (which is not IRD) to his son Alex. Alex pays the federal estate tax of $897,500. The [section 691(c) IRD] deduction goes equally to Jill and Holly because they received the IRD, even though Alex is the one who paid the estate tax.{{sfn|Choate|2006|p=125}} |}
Any taxable part of a distribution that is not income in respect of a decedent is a payment the beneficiary must include in income. However, the beneficiary cannot take any estate tax deduction for this part.
A surviving spouse can roll over the distribution to another traditional IRA and avoid including it in income for the year received.
==Inherited IRA with a basis== When an IRA owner passes with IRA basis documented on [https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-8606 Form 8606], the remaining basis is inherited by the beneficiary in proportion to the beneficiary interests.<ref>From forum member Alan S. Also see: {{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p590b/| title=Publication 590-B| publisher=IRS}} (IRA with basis)</ref>
If the beneficiary is a surviving spouse who rolls the IRA over to their own name or defaults to ownership by perhaps missing an RMD, the inherited basis is added to any basis the surviving spouse may have in their own IRA. The surviving spouse would then file their own 8606 which would result in their RMDs or other distributions being partially tax free.
If the inherited IRA is maintained in inherited form, any basis in the Inherited IRA would have to be kept separate from any basis the surviving spouse has in their own IRA by filing an 8606 for each labeled "owned IRA" or "Inherited IRA". If the surviving spouse does not have any basis in their own IRAs, it could be advantageous to keep the deceased's IRA with a basis in an Inherited IRA and withdraw from that instead of from their own IRA if money is needed before RMDs start in their own IRA. Withdrawing from an Inherited IRA before you turn 59 1/2 will also avoid any early withdrawal penalties.

'''{{PAGENAME}}''' is a court procedure where the validity of a will is proved or disproved. It involves all estate administration proceedings.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.americanbar.org/groups/real_property_trust_estate/resources/estate-planning/probate-process/| title=The Probate Process| publisher=ABA| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref>
When a person dies, all property, other than property passing directly to others (such as property held in joint tenancy, life insurance proceeds and retirement plans payable to a named beneficiary), may be subject to a probate proceeding.
An estate is generally probated in the county where the deceased owned property. If property is located in another state, additional proceedings are sometimes necessary in that state.
There is no natural right to inherit property. This right exists solely as granted by statute.
==Jurisdiction== In the US, probate is governed by each state's laws regarding inheritance and the administration of estates. In 1964 the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws drafted a Uniform Probate Code designed to update and standardize the nation's probate code. Eighteen states have adopted the code, with the remaining states adopting various sections of the code.<ref group="note">The states adopting the UPC include Alaska, Arizona, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Maine, Michigan, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Montana, Nebraska, New Jersey, New Mexico, North Dakota, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, South Dakota, Utah. See: [https://www.uniformlaws.org/committees/community-home?CommunityKey=35a4e3e3-de91-4527-aeec-26b1fc41b1c3 States adopting UPC]</ref><ref group="note">While Florida has adopted sections of the UPC, it retains material differences and is not universally considered a UPC state. See: [https://www.legalmatch.com/law-library/article/wills-trusts-and-estates-florida.html Wills, Trusts, and Estates Laws in Florida]</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/uniform_probate_code| title=Uniform Probate Code| publisher=Legal Information Institute| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref> A wide [[List of US state probate courts|variety of state courts]] will handle probate; commonly, district courts, circuit courts, probate courts, or another court. Probate is held in the county court where the deceased had residence. If the deceased holds real property in more than one state, a separate probate proceeding for each property is often required.
Every state offers some kind of shortcut for "small estates". Depending on where the estate is handled, the family may be able to skip probate court altogether or use a shortened, simplified version of probate.<ref group="note">For a list of probate "shortcut" laws for each state, see: [http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/probate-shortcuts-in-your-state-31020.html Probate Shortcuts in Your State], from Nolo.</ref>
Nolo.com spells out three types of probate:<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/how-probate-process-works-information-32438.html| title=The Probate Process for Executors| publisher=Nolo| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref>
*'''Informal probate''': Most probates in Uniform Probate Code (UPC) states are informal. This relatively simple process is used when inheritors are getting along and you do not expect problems with creditors. If anyone wants to contest the proceeding, you cannot use informal probate. The process is just paperwork; there are no court hearings.<ref group="note">[http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/how-probate-process-works-information-32438.html How the Probate Process Works: Information for Executors] from Nolo contains detailed information on the informal probate process.</ref> *'''Unsupervised formal probate''': In UPC states, it is a traditional court proceeding, much like the regular probate described above. It is generally used when there is a good reason to involve the court. For example, if there's a disagreement over the distribution of the estate's assets. You may need to get the court's permission before you sell the deceased person's real estate, distribute property to beneficiaries, or pay a lawyer. *'''Supervised formal probate''': The rarest form of probate. It is used only if the court finds it necessary to supervise the probate procedure, such as a beneficiary who cannot adequately look after their own interests and needs the court's protection. You must get court approval before distributing any property in this case.
==The probate process== If someone dies [https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/intestate intestate] (without a will) or disposes property by will, the estate will be subject to probate. The basic probate process includes the following steps: *Swearing in your Personal Representative (also referred to as executor/executrix or administrator/administratix); *Notifying heirs, creditors, and the public of your death; *Inventorying your property; *Paying bills, taxes, and distributing the estate, which can include the following costs: **Estate administration costs (legal advertising, appraisal fees, personal representative fees, attorney fees, and so on); **Family allowances (for support of family members); **Funeral expenses; **Taxes and other debts (medical bills, and so on); **All remaining claims; and **Whatever is left after creditors get their money is distributed to the beneficiaries named in the will. If there is no will, the laws in your state determine how and to whom the remaining property is distributed. Depending on the complexity of the estate, probate can take from three months to two or more years to complete.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.freeadvice.com/legal/step-by-step-guide-to-the-probate-process/| title=Step-by-Step Guide to the Probate Process| publisher=FreeAdvice}}</ref>
==The probate estate== {{See also | Asset titling in the United States}}
When someone dies, the property they owned is divided among property that is subject to probate, known as the probate estate, and the non-probate estate for property which can be directly passed on to beneficiaries. In general, assets held in living trusts, assets held in joint tenancy with rights of survivorship, and assets held in entities with beneficial interests (personal retirement plans, employer retirement plans, deferred annuity contracts, life insurance death benefits, payable on death (POD) accounts, and transfer-on-death accounts (TOD)) are not included in the probate estate, provided that beneficiaries are named, and that the estate is not the beneficiary.
One major difference between probate estate accounting and net worth accounting regards the value of indebted property (most applicable to real estate). While a net worth statement values real estate net of the mortgage value (for example a $1,000,000 home with a remaining $750,000 mortgage value would hold a $250,000 equity net worth value), the probate estate values the property without considering the mortgage. So the home would be valued at $1,000,000 dollars at probate, and probate fees would be applied to this value.

==Probate costs== Probate incurs costs. These costs include emotional and time costs in addition to the measurable financial costs. Probate's financial costs vary from state to state and are related to both the size and complexity of the probate estate. Probate costs can include:<ref>[https://www.fidelity.com/learning-center/life-events/what-is-probate Fidelity-What is probate, and how does it work?]</ref>
* Court fees * Appraisal and valuation fees * Account fees * Fees paid by the executor * Your attorney's fees to represent you in the process
In general, probate costs are estimated to range between 2% and 5% of the probated assets.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.thebalancemoney.com/how-to-avoid-probate-5667024| title=How To Avoid Probate| publisher=the balance| date=July 15, 2022| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref> However, in some states such as TX, where probate is generally uncomplicated, an uncontested estate with significant assets may cost significantly less than 2%. A clean, uncontested probate in Texas may cost $3,000-$7,000<ref>[https://everythingprobate.com/how-much-does-probate-cost-in-texas-breaking-down-the-expenses/ HOW MUCH DOES PROBATE COST IN TEXAS? BREAKING DOWN THE EXPENSES]</ref>, and the costs are mostly the same regardless of size.<ref>{{Forum link|title=Re:Disclaimer trusts — am I missing something?|p=8474369|author=Poster Eric (estate planning attorney)|date=August 12, 2025}}</ref> <ref>{{Forum link|title=Re:Disclaimer trusts — am I missing something?|p=8474550|author=Poster Eric (estate planning attorney)|date=August 12, 2025}}</ref> A few states (California, Iowa, Nevada, and Wyoming) have set fee schedules for probate costs, while other states use "reasonableness" or judicial discretion as the standards for probate fees. Attorney fees are often negotiable, although grieving survivors are often ill-suited for negotiating sessions.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://trustandwill.com/learn/probate-fees| title=Probate Fees: Costs by State Breakdown| publisher=Trust & Will| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref>

Overall, for all states combined, about ⅓ of probate cases are resolved for lawyer fees of $2,500 or under. About 45% of cases cost between $2,500 and $10,000 and roughly ¼ of cases cost upwards of $10,000. The cases with higher costs for the probate lawyer are almost undoubtedly larger and more complex estates.<ref>[https://www.legalmatch.com/law-library/article/the-cost-of-probate-a-state-comparison.html Legal Match-The Cost of Probate: A State Comparison]</ref>
==Avoiding probate== Given the costs, delays, and emotional toll of probate many people will seek to avoid the procedure. Keep in mind that the following property entities avoid probate:<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.findlaw.com/estate/probate/avoiding-the-probate-process.html| title=Avoiding the Probate Process| publisher=FindLaw| date=June 20, 2024| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref> * Assets held in a revocable living trust; * Assets held in joint tenancy; ** Joint Tenancy with a Right of Survivorship; ** Tenancy by the Entirety; ** Community Property with a Right of Survivorship; * Retirement accounts with properly designated beneficiaries; * Payable on death accounts (POD); * Transfer on Death Registrations (TOD).

Keep in mind that joint property will pass to the joint owner on the first joint owner's death, but the asset will be subject to probate on the second joint owner's death unless the property in retitled into a non-probate entity. For real estate, naming non-spouse beneficiaries (usually the children) is often not recommended since the surviving spouse would now be [[Asset protection|liable to the children's creditors]], and because the joint tenancy is irrevocable. An alternate strategy is to place the real estate in a revocable living trust. For jointly held savings bonds, the inheriting spouse can avoid probate costs be re-registering the savings bonds with a payable on death form (or hold them in a revocable living trust). Similarly, a joint bank account can be retitled as a payable on death account (or held in a revocable living trust).
One instance where probating an estate might prove beneficial is a situation where an estate has a large number of creditors. The probate procedure will place a time limit for creditors to make their claims on the estate. In this situation, an estate representative might decide to place a limited amount of estate assets sufficient to pay creditors into the probate process, while keeping the rest of the estate's assets in the non-probate estate.
Also, even if a decedent's estate is removed from probate, the estate must pay legitimate creditor claims and taxes due (both income and [[Estate and inheritance tax | estate or inheritance taxes]]). The estate representative should delay distributing the estate to beneficiaries until these claims are satisfied.
==Small estates==
Almost every state now offers alternatives to full probate for small estates.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/free-books/avoid-probate-book/chapter8-2.html| title=Small Estate Probate: Why Even Large Estates May Qualify| publisher=Nolo| date=May 15, 2025| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref> These may consist of a simplified probate process or a small estate affidavit that avoids the probate process entirely. The process can vary significantly between states.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.justia.com/probate/probate-administration/small-estates/small-estates-laws-and-procedures-50-state-survey/| title=Small Estates Laws and Procedures: 50-State Survey| publisher=Justia| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref> There are typically limits to the amount of applicable assets. The amounts can range from as low as $30,000 to as high as several hundred thousand dollars.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/avoid-probate-small-estate-29629.html| title=Small Estates: How to Avoid Probate| publisher=Nolo| date=June 21, 2022| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/small_estate| title=Small estate| publisher=Legal Information Institute| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref>
The two most common processes are a simplified probate process or a small estate affidavit. A small estate affidavit may allow you to avoid probate entirely. In some states like California there are different limits and affidavits for personal property and real property.
Beyond asset limits there are typically other restrictions that can make them more difficult to use. They often exclude any sort of debt, and if the deceased were to receive an unexpected cash inflow, such as a refund or a security deposit return, there may be no applicable bank account in which to deposit the funds.
The following is a podcast episode where an attorney discusses the potential pitfalls of a small estate process: * [https://www.bigpictureretirement.com/inbox-question-how-the-small-estate-affidavit-process-works/ How the small estate affidavit process works.]
==Family Settlement Agreement==
A family settlement agreement (FSA) is an informal contract between heirs used in some estates to [https://houston-probate-law.com/family-settlement-agreement/#:~:text=Fortunately%2C%20Texas%20law%20provides%20various,and%20a%20family%20settlement%20agreement. resolve estate distribution disputes] or to [https://www.floriolaw.com/trusts-estates/closing-estates-in-pennsylvania-understanding-the-fine-line-between-family-settlement-agreements-and-the-first-and-final-accounting/ close out the estate]. An FSA does not involve the courts. An FSA could be appropriate if the estate is fairly simple and all parties are willing to agree and abide by the FSA contract.

The purpose of this page is to describe and assess various '''asset protection''' strategies designed to mitigate the risk of financial ruin resulting from a lawsuit by an outside party.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asset_protection| title=Asset protection| publisher=Wikipedia}}</ref> {{quotation|Asset protection (sometimes also referred to as debtor-creditor law) is a set of legal techniques and a body of statutory and common law dealing with protecting assets of individuals and business entities from civil money judgments. The goal of all asset protection planning is to insulate assets from claims of creditors without concealment or tax evasion."|Wikipedia}}
This article does not address internal family matters, including divorce proceedings. It also does not address the ethics of asset protection.
==Insurance== Insurance can be required by law, or be electively purchased, to provide protection from certain potential liabilities. In addition, the cash values that build up in whole life, universal, and variable universal life insurance policies can be subject to creditor claims.
===Insurance for asset protection=== The following types of insurance allow individuals to purchase protection from liability claims.
*[[Auto insurance]] often covers both risks of property damage and needed medical care as a result of an incident involving a car. In most places, some degree of coverage is required by law in order to drive a car. Deductibles are usually available, and amounts and types of coverage are often highly customizable beyond the legally required minimum.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://personalinsure.about.com/cs/vehicleratings/a/blautominimum.htm| title=State-by-State Minimum Requirements| publisher=About.com}}</ref> *[[Homeowner's insurance]], [[renters' insurance]], and [[landlords' insurance]] generally provide coverage for loss of your own property and liability to others occurred because of their presence on your property. Deductibles are usually available. While a homeowner is paying off a mortgage on their house the lender will usually require homeowner's insurance, as may a buyer during the process of selling the house. There are always excluded perils, which means that if the loss is caused by one of those items then the insurance provides no coverage. There may be ways to cover these exclusions, either by riders amending the standard policy for an additional fee or by purchasing specialty insurance such as [[earthquake insurance|earthquake]] or [[flood insurance]]. *[[Professional insurance]] may take many names, depending on the profession, such as malpractice insurance or errors and omissions insurance. This insurance can protect the professional from paying directly for losses caused to their clients, and potentially others, by their work. *[[Umbrella insurance]] provides additional [[Liability Insurance | liability insurance]] above and beyond that contained in your other insurance policies. Umbrella insurance will generally need to be coordinated with the liability limits under those other policies.
===Life insurance cash values=== Federal bankruptcy law provides an exemption of $11,525 for the cash value of a life insurance policy in bankruptcy proceedings.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.thebankruptcysite.org/exemptions/federal.html| title=Federal Bankruptcy Exemptions| publisher=TheBankruptcySite.org| accessdate=May 22, 2025}}</ref> Additional liability protection against creditor claims to life insurance cash values is dependent on state law. In many cases it is also dependent on who is insured by the policy, who owns the policy cash values, and who is the beneficiary of the policy proceeds after the death of the insured. Some states protect all or a portion of the owner's cash value against creditors of the owner. Other states do not protect life insurance at all, or only protect proceeds that are paid to policy beneficiaries after the death of the insured.<ref>{{cite web|title=State-By-State Main Creditor-Debtor Exemption Chart, Note 4|url=https://www.assetprotectionbook.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=142&t=1566|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190304020115/https://www.assetprotectionbook.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=142&t=1566|archive-date=March 4, 2019|publisher=Riser and Adkisson forum}}</ref><ref group="note">According to R&A the following states provide protection for 100% of life insurance cash values: Arizona, Florida, Hawaii, Kentucky, Maryland, Michigan, New Mexico, New York, Oklahoma, Texas, Vermont, and Wyoming. The following states provide 100% protection for life insurance cash values with qualifications regarding who (usually restricted to spouse and dependents) is the beneficiary of the policy: Alabama, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Oregon, Puerto Rico, Tennessee, Virginia, and Washington. Two states, Iowa and Kansas, provide 100% protection of cash values with both beneficiary qualifications and, in addition, time restrictions applied to holding period.</ref>
==Splitting up assets between spouses==
If one spouse has high risk of liability and the other spouse has a low risk of liability, it is often in both spouses' interest to title some assets in the low-liability-risk spouse's name.
{| class="wikitable" |''Example'': :Dr. Smith is a obstetrician. She worries about being sued. She is married to Mr. Smith. He is a stay-at-home dad who believes he is at low risk of being sued. Half of their assets are owned by Dr. Smith. The other half are owned by Mr. Smith. If Dr. Smith is sued in a common law state, the funds in Mr. Smith's name generally cannot be seized by creditors because they are owned by Mr. Smith, not Dr. Smith. By contrast, if the funds had been held in a joint account, all of the assets would have been exposed to creditors. |}
[[File:800px-Community property states.svg.png|thumb|right|400px|Community property states]] To reduce the risk of this being deemed a "fraudulent conveyance," assets should be split up long before the high-liability-risk spouse is sued.
According to ''Modern Medicine'', however, splitting up assets is not a viable strategy in all states:<ref name="ModMed">{{cite web| url=https://www.modernmedicine.com/modernmedicine/article/articleDetail.jsp?id=111285| title=Protect your assets before you're sued}}{{dead link}}</ref>
{{quotation|Shifting assets to a spouse may be in vain in states that have community-property laws, such as California and Texas. There, a married couple jointly owns all property acquired during the marriage, even if it is titled in only one spouse's name, although exceptions are made for gifts, bequests, and the like. Generally, a creditor of one spouse can pursue the entire value of community property to satisfy a judgment.|Modern Medicine}}
An accounting firm, Kosmatka Donnelly & Co., provides the following example:
{| class="wikitable" |Joe and Judy reside in a community property state. Judy owns a bicycle rental business (which exposes her to potential lawsuits); Joe is semi-retired. Each month they deposit a portion of their income into a brokerage account titled in Joe’s name. The account assets are subject to the claims of Judy’s creditors because the account is community property. The fact that the account is in Joe’s name has no effect in a community property state.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.kdcocpa.com/docs/Transferring%20Assets%20to%20Low-risk.pdf| title=When Transferring Assets to a Low-risk Family Member Can Save the Day| publisher=Kosmatka Donnelly & Co.}}{{dead link}}</ref> |}
Wikipedia states that there are nine community property states in the United States: Arizona, California, Idaho, Louisiana, Nevada, New Mexico, Texas, Washington and Wisconsin.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_property| title=Community property| publisher=Wikipedia}}</ref>
According to the ''Modern Medicine'' article cited above, "[a] couple can beat [communty property laws] by signing a 'transmutation agreement' that converts jointly held property into separately held property."<ref name="ModMed"/>
Robert F. Kuegler, author of ''A Guide to Asset Protection: How to Keep What's Legally Yours'', elaborates:<ref>{{cite book| author=Robert F. Klueger| title=A Guide to Asset Protection: How to Keep What's Legally Yours| publisher=Wiley| date=1996| isbn=978-0-471-14885-2}}</ref> {{quotation|A transmutation agreement signed by spouses in a community property state says, in effect: "This is my property. It's my separate property. You have no interest in my property because we choose not to be governed by community property. Ditto for your property. I have no interest in it because it's your separate property...."|Robert F. Kuegler}}
Note that splitting up assets does not provide any protection to assets that remain in the name of the high-liability-risk spouse. Also, consider the tax consequences.<ref group="note">For example, while splitting ownership of assets (via transmutation agreement) in community property states may reduce risk from creditors, it comes at the cost of the loss of complete step-up valuation treatment of assets held as community property. See: [https://www.wwlaw.com/stepup.htm Step-Up In Basis].</ref> Finally, take into account the implications of this strategy in relation to divorce (both the risk of divorce and the fall-out in the event that divorce occurs).
==Investing in a primary residence== [[File:Bankruptcy exemptions map.jpg|thumb|right|400px|Homestead bankruptcy exemptions]] Many states offer a "homestead exemption," meaning that a resident's principal residence is partially or fully exempt from creditors. Laws vary significantly from state to state.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.legalconsumer.com/bankruptcy/laws/| title=50 State Homestead Exemptions & Other Bankruptcy Exemptions| publisher=Legal Consumer| accessdate=May 22, 2025}}</ref> Arkansas, Florida, Iowa, Kansas, Oklahoma, South Dakota, and Texas offer nearly unlimited homestead exemptions, subject to physical limits on the homeowner's acreage. In these states, a homeowner can shield millions of dollars from creditors via ownership of their primary residence.
The ''Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act of 2005'' limits a person's ability to move from one state to another to take advantage of a superior homestead exemption. This limitation applies only to those who have declared bankruptcy. Specifically, the Act imposes a ...<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.assetprotectionbook.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=76&t=261| title=Homestead Exemption - Overview| publisher=Adkisson and Riser forum}}{{dead link}}</ref> {{quotation|... limitation of the state homestead exemption in bankruptcy to $125,000, regardless of state law providing for a larger or unlimited exemption. This limitation applies to homestead interests that are acquired within a 1215-day (40 months) period prior to the filing of the bankruptcy petition.|Adkisson and Riser forum}} If you have violated the law, the limitation is $125,000 regardless of holding period.
==Investing in a 401(k)==
The ''Employee Retirement Income Security Act'' (ERISA) provides 401(k)s and other ERISA-governed retirement plans with rock-solid protection from creditor judgments.<ref name="WSJ">{{cite web | url=https://online.wsj.com/article/SB124181801239401917.html| title=How to Protect 401(k)s and IRAs From Creditors| publisher=Wall Street Journal| date=May 9, 2009}}</ref> This protection applies to judgments including bankruptcy, and it applies in all 50 U.S. states.<ref>{{cite web|title=Retirement Plans and ERISA FAQs|url=https://www.dol.gov/sites/dolgov/files/ebsa/about-ebsa/our-activities/resource-center/faqs/retirement-plans-and-erisa-compliance.pdf|access-date=|publisher=U.S. Department of Labor}}</ref>
[[Asset protection#Investing in an IRA |Individual Retirement Accounts (IRAs)]] do not receive those federal protections, although some states shield IRA assets from creditor judgments.
The language of the federal law governing rollover of assets from a 401(k) plan to an IRA is ambiguous. That law, the ''Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act'', states that $1 million in IRA assets is protected in bankruptcy without regard to amounts attributable to rollover contributions.
According to the ''Wall Street Journal'', "most experts say that phrase should be interpreted to mean that amounts rolled over from employer plans get creditor protection, as well. But others ... believe it means that the $1 million is determined 'without regard' to whether the amounts are attributable to rollovers."<ref name="WSJ" />
In short, maximizing contributions to a 401(k) plan is an excellent asset protection strategy. If you are thinking of rolling over assets from a 401(k) plan to an IRA, consider the asset protection implications carefully.
==Investing in a solo 401(k)==
A [[solo 401(k) plan]] offers some level of asset protection but not to the same degree as a standard 401(k) plan, because a solo 401(k) is not technically subject to ERISA regulations and protections.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irafinancialgroup.com/solo401kassetprotection.php| title=Solo 401K Asset Protection : Self Directed 401K : Solo 401K Creditor Protection : 401K Bankruptcy Protection| publisher=irafinancialgroup.com| accessdate=March 21, 2015}}</ref>
==Investing in an IRA== For anything other than a bankruptcy, state law determines protection of IRAs and Roth IRAs from creditors. Most states provide full protection. A list of state laws protecting IRAs is [https://www.thetaxadviser.com/content/dam/tta/issues/2014/jan/stateirachart.pdf available here].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thetaxadviser.com/issues/2014/jan/naegele-jan2014.html |title= Protection From Creditors for Retirement Plan Assets|author1=Richard Naegele|author2=Mark Altieri|date=January 1, 2014 |publisher=The Tax Adviser| access-date= September 25, 2016}}</ref>
At the federal level, the ''Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act of 2005'' provides traditional IRAs and Roth IRAs with an inflation-adjusted $1 million dollar cap exemption in federal bankruptcy proceedings. The act provides SEP and SIMPLE IRAs with a 100% exemption with no cap limit. Rollovers from employer plans have a 100% exemption with what most experts interpret to be no cap limit.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/081915/my-ira-protected-bankruptcy.asp#axzz1dh09aARA| title=Is My IRA Protected in a Bankruptcy?| publisher=Investopedia| accessdate=May 22, 2025}}</ref> However, retirement plan assets can be tapped for family support and the division of property at divorce. ==Qualified domestic relations order (QDRO) == A QDRO is a judgment, decree or order for a retirement plan to pay child support, alimony or marital property rights to a spouse, former spouse, child or other dependent of a participant.<ref name="QDRO">{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/retirement-plans/plan-participant-employee/retirement-topics-qdro-qualified-domestic-relations-order| title=Retirement topics — QDRO: Qualified domestic relations order | publisher=IRS| accessdate=May 22, 2025}}</ref>
A spouse or former spouse who receives QDRO benefits from a retirement plan reports the payments received as if they were a plan participant. The spouse or former spouse is allocated a share of the participant's cost (investment in the contract) equal to the cost times a fraction. The numerator of the fraction is the present value of the benefits payable to the spouse or former spouse. The denominator is the present value of all benefits payable to the participant.<ref name="QDRO" />
===Employer retirement plans=== A domestic relations order may assign some or all of a participant's retirement benefits to a spouse, former spouse, child, or other dependent to satisfy family support or marital property obligations if and only if the order is a "qualified domestic relations order." ERISA requires that each retirement plan pay benefits in accordance with the applicable requirements of any "qualified domestic relations order" that has been submitted to the plan administrator. The plan administrator's determinations on whether a domestic relations order is a QDRO, therefore, have significant implications for both the parties to a domestic relations proceeding and the plan.<ref>{{cite web|title=QDROs: The Division of Retirement Benefits Through Qualified Domestic Relations Orders|url=https://www.dol.gov/sites/dolgov/files/ebsa/about-ebsa/our-activities/resource-center/publications/qdros.pdf|publisher=U.S. Department of Labor}}</ref>
===Pensions=== When the DRO relates to a pension plan trusteed by PBGC ([https://www.pbgc.gov/about/ Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation]), PBGC must review it to make sure it is in line with ERISA, the federal pension law, as well as PBGC policies. If it is, PBGC qualifies the DRO, and it becomes a qualified domestic relations order, or QDRO. PBGC will pay benefits as the QDRO directs.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.pbgc.gov/wr/benefits/qdro| title=Qualified Domestic Relations Orders and PBGC | publisher=Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation| accessdate=May 22, 2025}}</ref>
==Investing in a 529 plan==
At the federal level, the ''Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act of 2005'' shields from creditor's [[529 plans#Asset protection advantages| 529 plan]] assets owned by a bankrupt beneficiary, provided the deposits meet certain criteria (for example, the deposits must have been made at least two years prior to bankruptcy).<ref name="CFed">{{cite web| url=https://cfed.org/knowledge_center/publications/savings_financial_security/state_creditor_protections_for_529_plans_a_seed_working_paper/| title=State Creditor Protections For 529 Plans: A SEED Working Paper| publisher=Corporation for Enterprise Development}}{{dead link}}</ref>
Many state laws provide protections as well, and unlike the federal legislation, the state-level protections apply to claims brought outside the bankruptcy process. For example, the following states provide creditor protection to both owners and beneficiaries of 529 plan assets: Alaska, Arkansas, Colorado, Florida, Kansas, Kentucky, Maine, North Dakota, Pennsylvania, South Dakota, Virginia, and West Virginia.<ref name="CFed" />
529 plans are easy and inexpensive to set up and maintain. The assets remain under the depositor's control. In some states the money deposited in a 529 plan is deductible from state income taxes.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://finaid.org/savings/state529deductions/| title=State Section 529 Deductions| publisher=Finaid| accessdate=May 22, 2025}}</ref>
==Investing in a variable annuity==
State law determines the extent to which an annuity's cash value or income payments are subject to creditor claims. Many states offer no protection. Some states offer limited protection to cash values and/or the income streams from annuitizing the contract. A number of states do offer 100% exemption of annuity cash values from creditor claims. These states include Arizona, Florida, Hawaii. Maryland, Michigan, New Mexico, Oklahoma, and Texas. Two other states offer 100% exemption of cash values after a minimum holding period: Kansas (if held more than one year) and Louisiana (if held for more than nine months).<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.assetprotectionbook.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=142&t=1566| title=State-By-State Main Creditor-Debtor Exemption Chart| publisher=Riser and Adkisson forum}}{{dead link}} (Note authors' disclaimers.)</ref> Variable annuity subaccounts are isolated from an insurer's general account, and so are protected against a sponsoring insurer's creditors in the case of an insurance firm default.
==Complex asset protection strategies==
===Forming a Limited Liability Company===
A Limited Liability Company (LLC) is a legal form of business company offering limited liability to its owners. If a wealthy person owns a business that is at high risk of liability, it is usually a good idea to transfer ownership of the business to a LLC. The purpose of doing so is to shield the person's personal assets from lawsuit risk.
{| class="wikitable" |''Example'': :John has millions of dollars in stocks and bonds and owns a junk-hauling company in his own name. One of his drivers is injured on the job and sues John. Because the hauling company is owned by John, his personal assets are exposed. He loses everything. Ten years later, John starts a new hauling business. It is successful and John is able to save millions of dollars once again. This time the hauling business is owned by an LLC, which in turn is owned by John and a business partner. When a driver is injured, John's attorney argues in court that it is the LLC that owns the business, so that John should be dropped from the lawsuit. If the judge agrees, then the injured driver can go after the assets owned by the LLC (trucks, for example) but not John's personal assets. |}
The problem with this strategy is that if the LLC appears to be sham rather than a bona fide business entity, a judge may allow litigants to bypass the LLC and go after the person's personal assets.
{| class="wikitable" |''Example'': :Sue is a retiree. She has millions of dollars in liquid assets. Her gardener slips in her driveway and sues Sue for $10 million. Sue has titled her home in the name of an LLC. The LLC does not operate a for-profit business, does not have a bank account, does not have stationery, does not have a website, does not have bylaws or an operating agreement. The LLC has no employees and no revenue. Sue's attorney argues that because the accident occurred at the home, Sue's gardener can sue the LLC but cannot sue Sue as an individual. Unfortunately for Sue, the judge concludes that the LLC is Sue and Sue is the LLC. In other words, the LLC is not a real business. The judge allows the gardener to sue for both the assets owned by the LLC and the assets owned by Sue. |}
There are many factors that a judge may take into consideration when deciding whether a LLC is a sham entity. A complete discussion of such factors is beyond the scope of this Wiki, but in general the more the LLC looks and behaves like an independent, bona fide business, the better.
Even though the LLC strategy does not provide bulletproof asset protection, it certainly makes it more difficult for litigants to seize someone's personal assets. By raising the costs of litigation and the cost of collection, LLC formation discourages potential litigants from suing in the first place. Forming an LLC is not very costly, making this a highly cost-effective strategy for people worried about liability risk arising from their business operations.
===Irrevocable trusts===
A trust is "a relationship whereby property (real or personal, tangible or intangible) is held by one party for the benefit of another."<ref>{{cite web| url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trust_law| title=Trust Law| publisher=Wikipedia}}</ref> The trust assets are managed for the beneficiaries by a trustee; either a person, such as a trusted friend, or an institution, such as Vanguard National Trust Company.
An irrevocable trust is a type of trust that cannot be changed after the trust is set up. As N. Brian Caverly and Jordan S. Simon put it, "After you place property into an irrevocable trust, you cannot retrieve the property. For all intents and purposes, that property now belongs to the trust, not to you!"<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.dummies.com/article/business-careers-money/personal-finance/estate-planning/revocable-versus-irrevocable-trusts-142979/| title=What is a Revocable Trust versus Irrevocable Trust| publisher=Dummies.com| accessdate=May 22, 2025}}</ref>
In contrast, a ''revocable'' trust allows you to revoke the rights of the trust; you control the assets. If you control the assets, your creditors can also control the assets. A revocable trust therefore provides no asset protection.<ref group="note"> After the death of the grantor of a revocable living trust, the trust becomes irrevocable. If the trust contains spendthrift provisions, the trust can provide protection from creditors and spouses. These spendthrift provisions are common in credit shelter trusts (A-B living trusts or testamentary credit shelter trusts) and in trusts that provide for deferred distribution of trust assets for beneficiaries. See Adkisson and Riser [https://web.archive.org/web/20190118012644/https://www.assetprotectionbook.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=260 Spendthrift Trust Overview] and [https://web.archive.org/web/20161020092319/https://www.assetprotectionbook.com/forum/viewforum.php?f=7 Spendthrift Trusts].</ref>
From an asset protection perspective, transferring assets from yourself to an irrevocable trust is a good thing, because a creditor (usually) cannot seize property that does not belong to you. Your family can be the beneficiaries of the irrevocable trust. So an irrevocable trust is a way to provide your family with financial support that is (usually) outside of the reach of creditors.
There are several significant drawbacks to bear in mind:
* Setting up and maintaining a properly-designed irrevocable trust is expensive, requiring an estate attorney to set up the trust and an accountant to deal with gift, inheritance, and estate tax implications. * Income tax rates for undistributed income in irrevocable trusts are high. See [https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-1041-es Form 1041-ES] for a current rate schedule. * Normally, the irrevocable trust is irrevocable, meaning once you have deposited your money into it you cannot get it back even if your circumstances change. * If a judge determines that you put the money in the irrevocable trust simply to evade creditors, they have the authority to "clawback" the money (that is, invalidate the trust).<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.lodmell.com/asset-protection-using-an-irrevocable-trust| title=Asset Protection Using an Irrevocable Trust?| date=August 16, 2010| accessdate=May 22, 2025| publisher=Lodmell and Lodmell}}</ref> This rarely occurs but is possible if, for example, the irrevocable trust is set up after you are sued.
===Off-shore trusts===
A Google search of "asset protection off-shore trusts" shows that off-shore trusts (trusts that hold assets in the name of a trust in a foreign jurisdiction) are recommended by numerous estate attorneys and asset protection consultants.
Most off-shore trusts are a type of self-settled spendthrift trust; that is, a trust that someone can establish for their own benefit, yet which purports to protect the trust's assets from creditors.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.assetprotectionbook.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=84&t=195| title=Lexicon of Asset Protection -- Complete List w/o Links| publisher=Riser and Adkisson forum| quote=Self-Settled Spendthrift Trust, Spendthrift Trusts}}{{dead link}}</ref> Self-settled spendthrift trusts are prohibited in most U.S. states. (But there are exceptions. See "Domestic asset protection trusts" section, below.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.assetprotectionbook.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=142&t=1566| title=State-By-State Main Creditor-Debtor Exemption Chart| publisher=Riser and Adkisson forum}}{{dead link}} (Note authors' disclaimers.)</ref>)
According to their advocates, off-shore trusts keep assets “out of the reach of creditors” because U.S. judges “do not have jurisdiction over foreign citizens.”<ref name="OffShore">{{cite web| url=https://www.offshorecorporation.com/offshore-trusts/| title=Offshore Trusts Provide Strong Asset Protection| publisher=Offshorecorporation.com}}{{dead link}}</ref> Typically, the trustee of an off-shore trust is not a U.S. citizen and does not reside in the U.S. Moreover, the countries where off-shore trusts are often created, such as the Cook Islands, Nevis, and Isle of Man, “do not recognize judgments that originate in a foreign country, such as the United States.”<ref name="OffShore" />
Off-shore trusts, however, are expensive to set up and administer—typically costing tens of thousands of dollars up front plus annual fees of at least several thousand dollars per year. They also may complicate a person's tax filings, and can make it harder for the grantor or beneficiary to access their funds.
Most importantly, off-shore trusts are less ironclad than is generally assumed. Attorney Jay Adkisson, an asset protection specialist, points out that U.S. judges may give debtors a choice between surrendering their off-shore assets or going to jail:<ref name="adkisson_chart">{{cite web| url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jayadkisson/2011/11/15/easy-chart-regarding-effectiveness-of-asset-protection-trusts/| title=Easy Chart Regarding Effectiveness Of Asset Protection Trusts| publisher=Forbes| author=Jay Adkisson| date=November 15, 2011| accessdate=May 22, 2025}}</ref>
{{quotation|Recent cases have recognized the power of courts to require debtors to bring their money back to the U.S. through what are known as ‘repatriation orders’. If the debtor does not comply with a repatriation order, a court may issue a bench warrant for contempt of court and hold you in contempt (and in jail) until the money does come back, or for many years. The record? It is 14 years in jail served by former corporate lawyer H. Beatty Chadwick who refused to repatriate money from overseas to pay alimony to his ex-wife.|Forbes}}
===Domestic asset protection trusts===
The flaws of off-shore trusts have led some estate planners to advocate domestic asset protection trusts. These are basically U.S. versions of off-shore trusts; that is, self-settled spendthrift trusts. Although most states prohibit these types of trusts, almost 20 states now allow them.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.kiplinger.com/retirement/all-about-domestic-asset-protection-trusts-dapts| title=Ins and Outs of Domestic Asset Protection Trusts (DAPTs) | publisher=Kiplinger| accessdate=May 22, 2025}}</ref> These trusts are less expensive to set up and maintain than their off-shore counterparts. But both domestic asset protection trusts and off-shore trusts provide highly imperfect protection from creditors.
Most importantly, the trustee of a domestic asset protection trust resides in the U.S. and so is under the jurisdiction of U.S. courts. Given that, the trustee may face a choice between going to prison or doing whatever a judge wants.<ref name="Facts">{{cite web| url=https://www.assetprotectioncorp.com/daptfacts.html| title=Facts about Domestic Asset Protection Trusts (DAPTs)| publisher=Asset Protection Corporation}}{{dead link}}</ref>
Also, someone who does not reside in one of the states that allows domestic asset protection trusts may not be able to persuade a judge that the law of other states where these trusts are legal should trump the laws of their own state. As the Asset Protection Corporation notes, "If you think you can get an Indiana judge to apply Alaska law in favor of an Indiana resident against an Indiana judgment held by an Indiana creditor which involves Indiana property? Well, you can just forget about that sort of thing happening."<ref name="Facts" /> Given that, domestic asset protection trusts appear to be better asset protection tools for those who live in one of the states that allows these trusts than for residents of other states.<ref name="adkisson_chart" />
==Living life carefully==
Perhaps the most effective asset protection strategy is to try to steer clear of activities that create liability. This means driving carefully, avoiding barroom brawls, and not owning a dangerous dog. It also means being discreet about your assets so as to avoid interest from would-be litigants.

According to the U.S. Internal Revenue Service, the '''[https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/estate-tax estate tax]''' "is a tax on your right to transfer property at your death. It consists of an accounting of everything you own or have certain interests in at the date of death."{{Cite web|date=September 14, 2022|title=Estate Tax|url=https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/estate-tax|access-date=September 25, 2022|publisher=IRS}} In addition to federal taxation, some states also impose an estate tax or an '''[https://www.investopedia.com/terms/i/inheritancetax.asp inheritance tax]''' on property transfers at death. An [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/e/estatetax.asp estate tax] is assessed on the deceased’s estate on the value of applicable estate assets prior to passing to heirs. An [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/i/inheritancetax.asp inheritance tax] is assessed on inherited assets and payable by the heirs. There is no federal inheritance tax, only a federal estate tax. At the state level, some states have estate taxes and a smaller number have inheritance taxes. As of 2025 only one state has both. Because of the high exemptions and state taxes only existing in some states, most investors will not pay any estate or inheritance tax. However, on large estates, the estate taxes owed can be very high, well into the millions of dollars. Fortunately, estate taxes can be reduced or eliminated through planning. See: [[#Estate_tax_planning|estate tax planning]] below. {{What is an estate?}} ==Assets included in the gross estate== {{Notice|Estate taxation, including issues involving trust and property titling and transfer, often requires professional guidance. [{{{url|http://www.irs.gov/uac/About-Publication-559}}} IRS Publication 559, Survivors, Executors, and Administrators] is designed to help those in charge (personal representatives) of the property (estate) of a person who has died (decedent). It shows them how to complete and file federal income tax returns and explains their responsibility to pay any taxes due on behalf of the decedent.}} In the U.S. a person's '''gross estate''' consists of the total fair market dollar value of all property and assets in which a person had an interest at the time of their death. The gross estate figure is the gross value of a person's estate before liabilities such as debt and taxes are deducted.{{cite web| url=https://www.investopedia.com/terms/g/grossestate.asp#ixzz23MnA38kE| title=Gross Estate: What It Is, How It Works, and Benefits| publisher=Investopedia| accessdate=July 4, 2025}} In addition to assets included in a person's [[Net worth|net worth]], the gross estate includes assets such as the death benefit value of life insurance (owned or controlled by that person) as well as certain additional property interests. In addition, how property is titled, for example, as sole property or the variations of joint property, determine what needs to be included in the gross estate.
