'''Estate planning''' is the branch of financial planning that deals with preparing for your own death or incapacity. The term "estate" refers to the legal entity that is created, and to which ownership of all your property is transferred, upon your death. An appointed executor then settles your estate by paying off any creditors and distributing the remaining assets to your beneficiaries; more details on this process are [[#Estate_settlement_process|below]]. Major goals of estate planning often include:
*Preparing for your temporary or permanent incapacity, for example by arranging for your financial affairs to be managed and medical decisions to be made on your behalf, and arranging for guardians for any dependents *Ensuring that your assets are distributed the way you want after you die *Streamlining the process of managing and distributing your estate. Avoiding [[probate]] (which can be expensive, time-consuming, and creates a public record of your assets) might be a goal, but the cost/benefit tradeoff for avoiding probate can vary greatly depending on your state's laws and individual situation. *[[#Tax_planning|Minimizing taxes]] (income tax, estate tax, gift tax, inheritance tax, capital gains tax, and so on) and streamlining the process of paying those taxes. As of 2025, the federal [[Estate_and_inheritance_tax|estate tax]] exemption is $13.99 million for individuals and $27.98 million for married couples.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/irs-releases-tax-inflation-adjustments-for-tax-year-2025#:~:text=Estates%20of%20decedents%20who%20die,%2418%2C000%20for%20calendar%20year%202024.| title=Estate tax| publisher=IRS| accessdate=Jan 1, 2025}}</ref> These limits increase to $15 million and $30 million, respectively, in 2026 and afterwards are indexed to inflation.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.thetaxadviser.com/news/2025/jun/details-of-tax-changes-in-senate-reconciliation-bill/| title=Tax provisions in the One Big Beautiful Bill Act| publisher=AICPA| accessdate=August 29, 2025}}</ref> Some [[Estate_and_inheritance_tax#State_estate_and_inheritance_taxes|states]] also have estate taxes, some with lower exemptions (as low as $1 million). If there is a chance you could owe federal or state estate tax, or if you have heirs who may owe state inheritance tax, additional planning is likely necessary.
In the United States, laws governing estates are mostly state-specific. Generally, investors should consult an estate planning attorney in their state who has experience with estates similar to their own. With a few exceptions (for example preparing your will when you have limited assets), estate planning is not a do-it-yourself project.
It is a common misconception that estate planning is only appropriate for those who are older, wealthy, or do not expect to [[Facing end of life|live much longer]]; nearly all adults would benefit from at least a simple estate plan. [[#Power_of_Attorney|Power of Attorney]] designations and an [[#Advance healthcare directive|advance healthcare directive]] are beneficial for almost any adult, and at least a simple [[#Wills|will]] is appropriate for anyone who owns property.
If you have minor children or other dependents, you should nominate a [[#Guardians_for_dependents|guardian]] in case you become incapacitated. Additional elements can be added depending on your situation and as your level of assets increases. This page is meant to give an overview of the estate planning process and the elements that make up estate plans for most investors.
==Major elements of estate plans==
===Power of Attorney===
A ''Power of Attorney (POA)'' is a legal document that authorizes someone else to act on your behalf; your agent (or agents) are formally called your ''attorney(s)-in-fact.'' There are two types of POAs - financial and medical - and if the term is used without reference to either, it usually refers to a financial Power of Attorney. A financial Power of Attorney may be also referred to as a “General” or “Statutory” Power of Attorney, depending on the state.
For estate planning purposes, financial Powers of Attorney should usually be "Durable" (DPOA), meaning your agents get this power immediately, and retain it if or when you become incapacitated or mentally incompetent.<ref group="note">Financial Powers of Attorney may also be ''Springing, General,'' or ''Limited.'' A Springing Power of Attorney (SPOA) only comes into force once you become incapacitated or mentally incompetent, which has the disadvantage of needing some sort of authority to determine incapacity. For this reason, DPOAs are usually preferable over SPOAs, though an SPOA may be preferred in certain situations. General and Limited POAs are only in force when you are competent and lose their force if you become incompetent, so are not useful for estate planning purposes.</ref> A financial power of attorney can act on your behalf to buy and sell property, pay bills, file tax returns, and handle many other transactions.
Your agents are legally required to abide by any specific instructions you give, and to act in your best interest when you have not given specific instructions; in this regard, they are your ''fiduciaries.'' They may be entitled to compensation for their time and effort, but only if the POA specifically permits it. Typically the POA explicitly authorizes the agents to be reimbursed for reasonable expenses they incur on your behalf.
Financial, General, and Statutory Power of Attorney documents can vary in breadth and format. The contents or format can also vary by state; some formats are an expansive list of powers that can span numerous pages, others follow a succinct and standard format that may only be a few pages. Beyond the standard powers given, certain special powers are often addressed separately and distinctly, requiring initials by each special power. Such special powers include gifting on behalf of the beneficiary, modifying beneficiary designations on behalf of the beneficiary and creating or amending trusts on behalf of the beneficiary.
A medical Power of Attorney (also known as a ''Healthcare Proxy'' or ''Healthcare Surrogate'') authorizes someone to communicate with healthcare providers and make medical decisions on your behalf, if you are unable to do it yourself, either temporarily or permanently. You should have both financial and medical POAs in place, and it is entirely possible, or even preferable, to have different people acting in each role. As long as you are mentally competent, you can change or revoke your Powers of Attorney at any time.
If you do not have a Power of Attorney in place and become incapacitated, your family will have to go to court and apply to have you declared incompetent, and have a conservator or guardian appointed by the court. Laws for this are state-specific. This process is expensive, time-consuming, and emotionally difficult. There is no guarantee the court will appoint the person or people you would prefer for this role. And, if you regain competency, it is very difficult to dissolve a conservatorship. That is why it is very important to have these documents in place, even if you have limited assets. All Powers of Attorney become void when you die.
Many financial institutions have their own Power of Attorney forms that they prefer you to fill out, in addition to a generic Power of Attorney form. In addition, they usually require a legal review and validation process that can take less than an hour in some cases and up to several weeks in other cases.
Other limitations could include prohibiting certain types of access (for example to business accounts), not accepting specific documents if they include old or outdated language, incorrect or outdated agent personal information (name, address, and so on) or certain types of administratively difficult POAs such as a joint POA, which potentially would require joint approval by all agents. For accounts that are likely to have activity (for example, main checking and investment accounts), it may be a good idea to file the institution-specific forms as well, to avoid challenges and make it easier on your agent.
You can find some anecdotal accounts of people who have had difficulty using their POAs in {{forum link| t=379848| title=When you find out your power of attorney is useless}}.
===Advance healthcare directive===
An ''Advance Healthcare Directive'' (also known as a ''Living Will'') is a document that specifies your medical wishes so that your medical Power of Attorney can make medical decisions on your behalf if you are unconscious, sedated, or otherwise incapacitated. For example, you might choose to specify:
*The conditions under which life-sustaining medical care should be withdrawn or withheld and you should be allowed to die (for example, if you are in a persistent vegetative state, or a Do Not Resuscitate [DNR] order if you are terminally ill) *The conditions under which pain-controlling and psychoactive drugs should and should not be administered *Prohibitions on certain drugs or procedures based on ethical or religious reasons (for example, no blood transfusions)
Even if your wishes are “standard” and do not include any unusual requirements, it is still important to create an Advance Healthcare Directive, so your loved ones will not be left wondering whether they made the right decisions on your behalf.
===Guardians for dependents===
If you have custody of any dependents (for example, minor children or disabled adults), you should create a document directing who will become the guardian (or conservator) of your dependents if you (and your spouse, if you have one) die or become incapacitated. It is usually suggested to specify a list of at least a few candidate guardians in rank order, in case some of the prospective guardians are unable to take on this responsibility (if they die, lose the capacity, or are unwilling) between when the document is written and when it is needed.
The laws and the use of terminology in this area can vary significantly between states. In many states, guardianship refers to personal and medical decisions, whereas conservatorship refers to financial decisions.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.legalzoom.com/articles/conservatorship-vs-guardianship| title=Conservatorship vs. Guardianship: Key Differences and Legal Guidance| publisher=LegalZoom| accessdate=August 29, 2025}}</ref> In states such as California guardianship refers to care of minors and conservatorship to incapacitated adults. In Texas it is the opposite, conservatorship relates to minors and guardianship to adults.<ref group="note">In TX guardian of the person refers to day to day care where as guardian of the estate refers to management of financial interests</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.ruelaslaw.com/guardian-of-the-estate-vs-guardian-of-the-person| title=Guardian of the Estate vs. Guardian of the Person| publisher=Ruelas Andino Law| accessdate=August 29, 2025}}</ref>
Consult with your estate planning attorney for advice on planning for your specific situation.
===Designated beneficiaries===
{{Warning|Listing designated beneficiaries on accounts is very easy to do (usually just a few clicks online) and '''overrides any wills and trusts.''' Therefore, it is easy to make mistakes when designating beneficiaries, and those mistakes often often have significant consequences. Estate planning attorneys report that designated beneficiary mistakes are among the most common issues when settling estates - such as accidentally leaving a large retirement account to an ex-spouse - and usually nothing can be done to fix it after-the-fact. Make absolutely sure your designated beneficiaries are up-to-date and consistent with your overall estate plan.}}
Many types of accounts can have ''designated beneficiaries'' or an equivalent. Qualified accounts ([[IRA]]s, [[401(k)]]s, and so on) allow for assignment of direct designated beneficiaries. Bank accounts have a Payable on Death (POD)<ref group="note">Technically, a Payable on Death account is known as a Totten Trust, which behaves like a simplified trust that passes assets to heirs outside of a will and probate. However, it lacks many of the capabilities of traditional trusts, such as allowing the grantor to control the timing of when assets are distributed to beneficiaries.</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://trustandwill.com/learn/totten-trust?srsltid=AfmBOorjWdFOawri7UdOAZ1JLsQOtRG_uB6DumWra2r6WyN2Moqc1Pyg | title=Totten Trust: Using POD Designations to Avoid Probate| publisher=Trust & Will| accessdate=Jan 11, 2025}}</ref> designation and [[Taxable account|taxable accounts]] have a Transfer on Death (TOD) designation; see [[Asset_titling_in_the_United_States#Beneficiary_designation|Beneficiary designation]]. These features allow ownership to pass directly to heirs at death, rather than first going to the estate and then distributed through probate, which takes time and money, and creates a public record of your assets.
Designating beneficiaries directly is the most common and efficient way to pass on assets in qualified/retirement accounts. This method allows the beneficiary to maintain the longest allowable RMD stretch available: spouses can treat the account as their own, [[Stretch_IRA#SECURE_Act_inherited_IRAs|Eligible Designated Beneficiaries]] get a stretch over their life expectancy, most other designated beneficiaries can stretch over 10 years. Retirement account designated beneficiaries can be directly to individuals or to [[Trusts|trusts]]. If a trust is the designated beneficiary, care must be exercised drafting the trust and assigning trust beneficiaries such that the beneficiaries full allowable stretch is maintained.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.investopedia.com/terms/s/seethrough-trust.asp| title=See-Through Trust: Meaning, Overview, Alternatives| publisher=Investopedia| accessdate=Jan 4, 2025}}</ref>
Designating beneficiaries for taxable accounts (TODs, PODs) can have some drawbacks. <ref>{{Forum link|title= Re: Beneficiary question|p=8499773 |author=bsteiner|date=August 31, 2025}}</ref> Examples include:
*The estate will need money for debts, potential income or estate taxes, and other expenses. If insufficient funds are left over after the direct transfers, then the executor is left trying to deal with the shortfall. *While assigning TOD/POD beneficiaries is very simple, it is often not very flexible. If primary or contingent beneficiaries die out of expected sequence, assets may end up being allocated in a less than optimal manner. *It may be better to pass on taxable assets via a [[Trusts|trust]] as opposed to doing so through TOD or POD directly to an individual. See: [[Trusts#Leaving_assets_directly_vs._in_trust|Leaving assets directly vs. in trust]]. *Because designated beneficiaries are easy to change and take precedence over a will, there is a higher chance of making a consequential error. *Care must be exercised to make sure the preferred designation methodology is elected, [https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/per_capita per capita] or [https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/per_stirpes per stirpes].<ref>[https://trustandwill.com/learn/difference-between-per-stirpes-and-per-capita/ Trust&will - Per Stirpes vs Per Capita - What’s the Difference?]</ref> Failing to do so may allocate assets in an unwanted manner if one of the beneficiaries dies before the original owner dies. *In many if not most states, divorce revokes designated beneficiary provisions for the former spouse other than for ERISA plan benefits since Federal law supersedes state law as to ERISA plan benefits. So ERISA plan participants (such as 401k and other employer plans) have to affirmatively change beneficiary designations if they want to remove their former spouse.<ref>{{Forum link|title=Re: Proposed major expansion to Estate Planning wiki page - plus two new pages|p=8369519|author=bsteiner|date=May 9, 2025}}</ref>
Talk to your estate planning attorney to weigh the pros and cons of leaving assets to designated beneficiaries for your individual situation. To the extent they are used, review designated beneficiaries on all your accounts and make sure they are up-to-date with your current wishes, and your overall estate plan.
===Wills===
A ''will'' is a legal document that specifies who will take ownership of your property after you die. Note that many types of property can have [[#Designated_beneficiaries|designated beneficiaries]] where ownership passes to your heir without being listed on a will or going through [[probate]].
As a general rule, everyone who owns a significant amount of property should have a will. Wills are most important when you have valuable assets that cannot have designated beneficiaries (for example real estate, cash, precious metals, jewelry, artwork, collectibles). The value of a will is reduced in situations where all your valuable assets have designated beneficiaries (for example, retirement accounts and investments), but even in this case, you should still specify who will inherit your car, personal effects, and similar.
If you die without a will, your state will consider you to have died ''[https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/intestate intestate]'' and will distribute your assets per the state’s ''[https://www.findlaw.com/estate/planning-an-estate/intestate-succession-laws-by-state.html laws of intestacy]'' – these usually specify an order of family members who will inherit your property. Even if you are okay with your assets being distributed according to state law, these laws may change between now and when you die and you might not realize it, so at least a simple will is recommended for anyone who owns property.
Creating a simple will can be done easily and for no cost. The internet has plenty of resources to help you create a simple will on your own, including templates you can download and fill in. If there could be any doubt about your mental capacity when you sign your will, work with an estate planning attorney who can advise you on how to ensure your will will be accepted by the court. Wills can also be used as part of more complex estate plans (such as a ''[https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/pour-over_will pour-over will]'' for assets that might not pass through a [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/r/revocabletrust.asp revocable living trust]). Your estate planning attorney will be able to advise you about wills in these situations too.
====Probate==== {{Main|Probate}}
Probate is the legal process of validating a will (the word "probate" has the same root as "prove") and distributing your assets according to that will. Probate happens in court in front of a judge. The probate process is state-specific. Assets that pass to heirs by designated beneficiaries and those already inside trusts do not go through probate.
Probate has some downsides: it takes time, costs money (at least in terms of lawyer's fees), and creates a public record of your assets. Depending on the state, probate can also have expenses or fees imposed by the state government. While there is near-universal agreement that avoiding probate in some states (such as California) is worth significant effort, estate planning attorneys may have differing opinions on the value of avoiding probate in states where it is relatively easy and inexpensive. Your attorney can advise you on the costs and benefits of avoiding probate in your state, but there may be more than one reasonable option.
Most states now have a simplified process for the administration of [[Probate#Small estates|small estates]]. Another alternative available in some states for simple estates is a [[Probate#Family Settlement Agreement|family settlement agreement]].
===Trusts=== {{Main|Trusts}}
Trusts can be either revocable or irrevocable, and are used for many purposes, such as leaving assets to minors or spendthrifts, protecting assets from potential creditors, avoiding estate taxes, and charitable giving. Assets typically pass to such trusts either through the will (testamentary trusts) or as part of a revocable living trust. Sometimes assets are titled directly to a trust. See the main article for more details.
===Letter of instruction===
A ''letter of instruction'' (sometimes called a ''death book'') is a general term for a letter you leave behind to surviving family or others who may have an interest in your affairs after you die. A letter of instruction is not legally binding on anyone, so if you want any of these instructions to be legally binding, consult with your estate planning attorney to discuss options. A letter of instruction may include things like:<ref>{{forum link| t=198919| author=[[Taylor Larimore]]| title=Letter of Final Instructions| date=September 5, 2016}}.</ref>
*Contact information for your estate planning attorney or other important people *Your wishes for funeral arrangements, such as whether you will be buried or cremated, where you would like to be buried or have your ashes scattered, what memorial service you would like. *Especially if you are the primary money manager of the household, your plan for who will take over this responsibility; see [[#Continuity_of_financial_management|below]]. *Account numbers, passwords, locations of documents, and other important financial information that will be necessary to continue managing finances for your family, or for your estate *Letters to loved ones, or other personal information you may want to share
==Tax planning==
Minimizing taxes is often a goal of estate planning, especially when larger levels of assets are involved. This section contains a non-exhaustive list of tax-reducing strategies that are sometimes part of estate plans.
===Estate tax planning and avoidance=== {{Main|Estate and inheritance tax}}
An ''estate tax'' is a tax on property passed to others after you die. As of 2025, the federal estate tax exclusion is $13.99 million for a single individual, and $27.98 million for a married couple; tax is only assessed on assets above these values. These limits increase to $15 million and $30 million in 2026 and are indexed to inflation afterwards. Due to these high limits, only a small percentage of taxpayers will owe federal estate tax. However, the federal estate tax rate is very high: as of 2025, '''40%''' for all assets above the exclusion. When federal estate taxes are owed, it is usually millions of dollars. Some states also assess [[Estate_and_inheritance_tax#State_estate_and_inheritance_taxes|state estate tax]], and some have lower exclusions, as low as $1 million. State estate tax rates are typically around 16%. For those who will possibly or likely owe estate tax, additional planning is necessary.
Estate tax planning typically has two goals: minimizing the tax owed, and ensuring any tax owed can be paid easily. See [[Estate_and_inheritance_tax#Estate_tax_planning|Estate tax planning]] for more details.
The most obvious estate tax avoidance strategy is the use of [[Estate_and_inheritance_tax#Portability_for_married_couples|portability]], which transfers the unused portion of the first-to-die spouse's estate tax exemption to the surviving spouse. Federal estate tax exemption portability is '''not automatic''' - you must elect to port over your deceased spouse's remaining exemption by filing a U.S. Estate, Gift, and Generation-Skipping Return ([https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-706 Form 706]). This might be a good idea even if you do not expect to pay estate taxes, because the exemption could be lowered, you could have very good investment returns, you could receive an inheritance, and so on. If you might owe state estate tax, plan to either file the appropriate forms to get portability (if your state has portability - most do not) or consider more complex planning techniques using [[trusts]] to achieve the same effect.
Another common estate tax avoidance strategy is to gift money while you are alive. The federal gift tax exclusion is $19,000 per person per year as of 2025, meaning gifts of up to this amount are not subject to [[gift tax]].<ref group="note">When you make gifts to someone over the gift tax exclusion in a given year, you are required to file a [https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/about-form-706 Gift tax return]. Usually, no tax is due immediately, but the amount of gift above the exclusion gets subtracted from your lifetime exemption. After you die, your estate taxes will be calculated using the reduced exemption. In the case where you use up your entire lifetime exemption with un-excluded gifts while you are alive, you will owe gift tax on any further un-excluded gifts in the year you make the gift, which is effectively pre-paying estate taxes. If it is very unlikely you will owe estate tax, making gifts above the annual exclusion is not a big deal, because it is very unlikely to cost you any tax (although filing the gift tax return is a minor hassle). But if it is likely you will owe estate taxes, take care before making gifts above the annual exclusion because of the high tax rate you may pay.</ref> When the giver is married, this amount doubles, because both spouses get their own limit, and when the recipient is married, the amount doubles again because gifts can be given to both spouses. Payments made directly to educational institutions or healthcare providers on behalf of someone else are also free of gift tax, regardless of size. For high levels of assets, placing assets in [[trusts]], where future growth will occur outside your future estate, is usually part of the plan.
If you will owe estate tax, make sure there will be enough cash inside your estate to pay the bill. For example, if most of your assets are taxable investments and retirement accounts, and these are left directly to beneficiaries, your executor may need to recover some of these assets from your beneficiaries to pay the estate tax. If your beneficiaries do not cooperate, your executor will need to sue them to recover money.
Predicting your estate value and the future estate tax exemption when you die are extremely difficult, so estate tax planning is an inexact science. Make the most reasonable assumptions you can given your situation, periodically check your plan, and adjust as needed. For high levels of assets, consulting an estate planning attorney with experience in estate tax planning can be extremely valuable.
===Step-up in basis=== {{Main|Step-up in basis}}
With very few exceptions, whenever you leave [[Taxable account|taxable]] assets (that is, assets not inside a special account like an [[IRA]], [[401k]], [[Health savings account|HSA]], etc.) to an heir, the ''cost basis'' (generally, the price you paid for it) on which any capital gains taxes are calculated gets ''stepped up'' to the value on the date of your death. This feature of the US tax code can be very valuable, especially for assets that have the potential to appreciate a lot, like [[Stock basics|stocks]], real estate, and collectibles. For example, if you own $250,000 of stock-based [[Mutual fund|mutual funds]], for which you paid $50,000 many years ago, and sell them the day before you die, you would owe capital gains tax on $200,000 of gains. But if you leave the mutual funds to your heirs and they sell them the day after you die, they would receive the full $250,000 tax-free.
As you get older, it generally becomes less desirable to sell appreciated taxable assets, so you can preserve the step-up in basis for your heirs. However, there are drawbacks to withdrawing from retirement accounts too - specifically, the loss of fully tax-deferred growth and the 10-year [[Stretch IRA|stretch]] for heirs, and potential loss of [[asset protection]]. The optimal order to draw down assets depends on many factors; some examples for combinations of owner and heir tax rates and owner life expectancy are listed here: [[Retirement_draw-down_priority#Tapping_taxable_investments_or_retirement_accounts|Tapping taxable investments or retirement accounts]]. Another option to raise cash from appreciated taxable assets that preserves the step-up in basis is to borrow against them, for example with a home equity loan or margin loan. Your heirs can pay off the loan after your death by selling the assets with a stepped-up basis.
Assets inside a [[Trusts#Revocable_Living_Trusts_(RLTs)|Revocable Living Trust]] also get a step-up in basis when the grantor dies, as though they were owned outright. However, assets inside a ''non-grantor irrevocable'' trust typically do not get a step-up in basis, because the owner (the trust) does not die. The loss of a step-up in basis is a downside of placing assets in irrevocable trusts, which must be weighted against the potential benefits. When federal estate taxes are being avoided, the numbers favor avoiding the estate tax (avoiding 40% on the entire value vs. up to 23.8% on just the gains).
===Roth conversions=== {{Main|Roth conversion}}
Roth conversions can be a powerful tool for end-of-life tax planning. If you plan on leaving retirement accounts to heirs, and can convert pre-tax money to Roth at a lower rate than you expect them to pay when they withdraw the money, it will increase the after-tax value of your bequest. Consider also that the SECURE Act requires non-spouse heirs to distribute retirement accounts within 10 or 11 years, so leaving a large pre-tax account ''per heir'' can raise their marginal tax rate much higher than it is now.
For example, consider if you have a $2 million pre-tax IRA and a single heir with an $80,000 income in the 22% bracket. If the heir expects 5% real growth and can withdraw the funds over 11 years, per the [[Stretch_IRA#Level_withdrawals|level withdrawal table]] that would add $228,400 (=$2,000,000 x 11.42%) of taxable income, raising them into the 35% bracket. That would suggest some Roth conversions at 24%, 32%, and even 35% (if the taxes can be paid with other taxable assets) could be beneficial. However, if the IRA were worth $200,000, or the same $2 million IRA were left to ten heirs in similar tax situations in equal amounts, the $22,840 income would not affect their marginal tax rate, and the decision can be made based on the heirs' marginal tax rates today.
Roth conversions where the taxes can be paid from funds outside the conversion are even more beneficial than when the taxes are paid with converted funds, as the analysis [[Traditional_versus_Roth#Maxing_out_your_retirement_accounts|here]] shows. The time to withdrawal can be taken to be the owner's life expectancy plus the ten year distribution period. However, realizing capital gains on taxable assets to raise the funds needed to pay the tax is probably not optimal, as those assets should receive a [[Step-up in basis|step-up in basis]].
Roth conversions can also have benefits when federal and/or state [[Estate and inheritance tax|estate taxes]] will be owed. Theoretically, the [[Income_in_respect_of_a_decedent|Income in Respect of a Decedent]] deduction for heirs can equalize ''federal'' taxes with respect to Roth conversions. But, there are still several potential advantages to leaving Roth money even when taxes are equal. And, there is no federal deduction for [[Estate_and_inheritance_tax#State_estate_and_inheritance_taxes|state estate taxes]], so Roth conversions can be a benefit when state estate taxes will be owed. See [[Traditional_versus_Roth#Estate_planning|Traditional versus Roth - Estate planning]] for more details.
Roth conversions when large pre-tax balances are involved can be a complex math-intensive decision with many assumptions. If you are in this situation, consider using a [[Roth_conversion#Summary_of_tools|software tool]] to help with the analysis, or hiring a qualified fee-only [[financial planner]].
==Insurance==
The most common types of insurance worth considering for estate planning purposes are [[life insurance]] and [[disability insurance]]. Other types of insurance (health, property, liability, and so on) are needed by most people for at least some of their lives, but are beyond the scope of this article as they are not estate planning-specific. Like all insurance, life and disability insurance have a negative [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value expected payout] - that is, ''on average'' you should expect to lose money when purchasing insurance.
For this reason, virtually every expert recommends insuring only against financial catastrophes, where the protection is worth an expected loss of a percentage of the premium paid, and [[Insurance#Self_insuring|self-insuring]] against non-catastrophic risks. When they are needed, both life and disability insurance usually insure against large losses where self-insuring would be difficult.
===Life insurance=== {{Main|Life insurance}}
Life insurance pays a death benefit to the policy beneficiary when the insured person dies. The typical situation when life insurance is appropriate is insuring the life of a working spouse when the surviving spouse would not be able to take care of the family's dependents (usually minor children) without their income. If both spouses work, but neither would be able to support the family without the other's income, life insurance is needed on both spouses. Even if one spouse does not earn an income, they probably contribute to the household in other ways - for example, working inside the home or doing unpaid work in the family business - and they may need life insurance to cover the cost of hiring help to replace this work.
Single individuals, couples without dependents, and children typically do not need life insurance on their lives.
''How much'' life insurance to buy can take some work to determine; see: [[Life_insurance#Determining_family_life_insurance_needs| Determining family life insurance needs]].
For several reasons, '''term''' life insurance is almost always the best way to get the coverage you need. A term policy covers the insured for a specified term (for example, 30 years) as long as premiums are paid on schedule. If the insured dies during the term, the policy pays the face value. If the insured does not die by the end of the term, the policy simply expires.<ref group="note">Some term policies have features where they can be converted to permanent policies or extended on an annual basis. The costs for doing so are typically very high, and such options would only make sense to exercise if the chances of the insured dying are high. While these features are nice to have in the low chance they are valuable, it is not worth paying a lot of extra money to get a term policy with these features. In the rare cases where permanent insurance is needed, it is more cost-effective to purchase it from the outset.</ref> Except in rare cases, life insurance is only needed for a certain term, because by necessity almost all couples will be financially independent by retirement age. Competitively-priced term policies are cheap, so most experts recommend rounding up on both the policy value and term for conservatism.
In contrast to term policies, ''permanent'' life insurance policies provide a death benefit for the insured's entire life. There are many types of permanent policies, such as Whole Life, Indexed Universal Life, Guaranteed Universal Life, and others. Permanent life policies have the character of both an investment and an insurance policy, and are much more complex than term policies, and non-standardized between insurers. The premiums are much larger than a term policy with the same death benefit.
Permanent policies are only appropriate in ''rare'' estate planning situations where there is a need for both insurance that lasts someone's entire life, and the need to leave a guaranteed amount of money. An example could be when [[#Estate_tax_planning_and_avoidance|estate taxes]] will be owed on an illiquid estate - for example, a valuable family business with limited liquid assets. Permanent policies often pay large sales commissions to insurance agents, which might explain why some market permanent policies aggressively. However, the overwhelming consensus among financial experts is that permanent policies should ''not'' be used just for insuring a spouse's income and/or for general investing.
===Disability insurance=== {{Main|Disability insurance}}
Disability insurance insures against your loss of income because of an inability to work due to disability. If you become disabled, the policy pays you a monthly income. It is usually appropriate in the same situations as life insurance (insuring a working spouse's income, or the value of their unpaid work), and others too. If a single person with no dependents becomes disabled, they will need income to pay for normal living expenses, and possibly other expenses, such as home health aid. If the combination of their assets plus any government assistance (for example, state and Social Security disability payments) would not be sufficient to maintain an acceptable standard of living, a disability policy would be needed to make up the difference.
If you need disability insurance, it is usually wise to purchase as much as you can. If you become disabled, the monthly payments need to cover all your expenses, and you also need to save for retirement, because most disability policies stop paying around age 65.
Disability insurance is much more expensive than term life insurance, because you're much more likely to become disabled than die young. Policies vary in how they define disability, how they handle partial disability, and so on. They also have an ''elimination period'' you have to wait before being able to file a claim, analogous to a deductible. A good independent insurance agent (that is, one who is not "captive" to a particular insurer and can only sell their policies) can work with you to find a policy suited for your particular needs. Also see the [[Disability insurance|main page]] for details.
==Gifting and titling==
Unless there is a chance you will owe federal or state [[Estate_and_inheritance_tax|estate tax]], there is generally not a tax advantage to gifting assets during your lifetime, and there could be a tax cost if you gift assets with unrealized gains that would otherwise receive a [[step-up in basis]] (or sell them and realize the gains yourself). However, there could be non-financial reasons to gift during your lifetime, such as being able to see the positive effects of your gifts on your loved ones. You can gift up to the annual gift exclusion of $19,000 (as of 2025) per person per year without any tax impact or forms to file, and this amount doubles if either the giver or receiver are married (the spouse can give or receive too), and quadruples if both are married. If you gift to any one person above the gift exclusion in a given year, you will have to file a [[gift tax]] form, but no taxes are owed until your un-excludable lifetime gifting exceeds the estate tax exemption.
Similarly, it is a common misconception that it is wise to transfer asset title to heirs before you die, or add them as [[Asset_titling_in_the_United_States|joint owners]], for estate planning reasons. These maneuvers often forego part or all of the step-up in basis that the asset would otherwise receive, and can sometimes complicate asset liquidation. If avoiding [[probate]] is a concern, using a [[Trusts|trust]] is usually a much better solution.
However, gifting during your lifetime can play a major role in [[#Estate_tax_planning_and_avoidance|estate tax planning]] if you expect to pay estate taxes.
==Charitable giving==
You may choose to make charitable giving part of your estate plan, especially if your expected estate is large. The simplest way is to leave a portion of your assets to charities via a [[#Wills|will]] or [[#Designated_beneficiaries|designated beneficiaries]]. Charitable gifts are excluded from your taxable estate, and so will reduce your [[#Estate tax planning and avoidance|estate tax]] bill if you would owe estate taxes. Usually, the priority for leaving assets to charity to minimize taxes is as follows:
#[[Health Savings Account|Health Savings Accounts (HSAs)]]. When a non-spouse inherits an HSA, as the entire balance is taxable income in that year, with no stretch. Charities do not pay taxes on donations, including from HSAs. #Pre-tax retirement assets, including [[Traditional IRA|traditional IRAs]], [[401(k)|401(k)s]] and [[403(b)|403(b)s]]. Heirs will have to pay taxes on these withdrawals but charities do not. Heirs get some form of [[Stretch IRA|stretch]] depending on the circumstances, so the entire balance does not need to become taxable income in a single year. #[[Taxable account|Taxable]] assets, including cash, cash-like accounts like checking accounts and money markets, brokerage accounts, life insurance, real estate, and collectibles. These assets get a [[step-up in basis]] at death, so there is no benefit to preferentially [[donating appreciated securities]]. These assets have equal after-tax value to heirs and charities. #[[Roth IRA|Roth]] assets. These assets are usually tax-free to heirs, and also allow a tax-free [[Stretch IRA|stretch]]. So, they are more valuable to heirs than taxable assets but equally valuable to charities, and should be the lowest priority for charitable giving.
In addition to simple bequests, there are more complicated arrangements for charitable giving from an estate, such as using trusts like a [[charitable remainder trust]], which are beyond the scope of this page.
==Continuity of financial management==
If you are the primary manager of financial issues in your family and would leave behind a spouse who is not as familiar with the subject, you should work with your spouse to create a plan for how family finances will be managed if you die or become incapacitated. This plan should reflect your spouse’s willingness and ability to handle the various facets of the family finances. This plan should include:
*A complete list of financial information, including: **Accounts - firm names, account numbers, account types, approximate value **Debts (including credit cards) - account number, interest rate, approximate balance **Insurance policies - insurer, account number, insurance type, premium and frequency **Valuable physical property (precious metals, jewelry, art, coins, collectibles, savings bonds, etc.) – location, description, approximate value **Recurring bills (for example, utilities) – firm, account number, approximate amount **Location of important papers (tax returns, property deeds, contracts, and so on) **Contact information for important people – accountant, estate planning attorney, business contact, contractors who work on the house, etc. **User names and passwords *Actionable steps for your spouse to take in the event of your death, such as: **Notify important people (employers, estate planning attorney, accountant, etc.) **Notify life insurance carriers and collect life insurance **Place 6-12 months of cash in the main checking account to allow time to mourn without worrying about finances **File for Social Security survivor benefits **Sell certain investments **Pay off certain debts **Consolidate accounts **Send the last few years of tax paperwork to the accountant **Handle any business succession issues, such as dissolving a business or selling shares of a partnership *A list of ongoing tasks your spouse will be responsible for, such as: **Rebalancing investments **Periodically making investment contributions or withdrawals, when the checking balance gets too high or low **Taking [[Required Minimum Distribution|Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs)]]
It probably makes a lot of sense to pick out one or a few high-quality fee-only [[Financial planner|financial planners]] your family can use once they take over managing the family finances. You can tailor the choice of advisor to your surviving family's expected needs, which could be anywhere between full-service financial and investment management to a per-hour consultation when complex issues arise. In addition, it could be helpful to pick other financial professionals your family may need, such as an accountant for tax preparation. If you will need a trustee for a [[Trusts|trust]], see: [[Trusts#Trustees|Trustees]].
Following your death, your spouse will probably be dealing with serious emotions and will not have their full capacity for dealing financial and legal matters. Therefore, you should tailor your estate plan to make it as easy as practical for your surviving family, especially at first. Over time, as they gather experience and emotional wounds heal, they can grow into the responsibility. See also: [[Managing a windfall]] for advice targeted at survivors who inherit a large amount of money.
==Estate settlement process==
An estate is automatically created when a person dies, and becomes the owner of their property, except for property owned by their trust (if they have one) or any assets with [[Asset_titling_in_the_United_States#Beneficiary_designation|designated beneficiaries]]. An executor is appointed to manage their estate until it is settled. Typically, the decedent names their desired executor in their will, although this person is not obligated to accept the role, which comes with substantial responsibilities. An executor can also be appointed by the court. The executor has a wide range of responsibilities, which include:
*Find the decedent's will (if one exists) *Inventory all of the decedent's assets, including getting any valuable ones appraised if necessary *Secure and manage the decedent's assets, including things like paying bills, managing investments, arranging for maintenance on properties, making sure property is/remains appropriately [[Insurance|insured]], making sure cars are parked appropriately, etc. *Determine whether [[probate]] is necessary, and if so, initiate probate proceedings *If full probate is unnecessary, evaluate whether [[Probate#Small estates|small estates]] procedures or a [[Probate#Family Settlement Agreement|family settlement agreement]] are viable options. *Notify relevant parties of the decedent's death (banks, utility companies, post office, Social Security Administration, etc.) *Hire any necessary lawyers, accountants, or other professionals *Notify beneficiaries named in the will or otherwise entitled to inherit the decedent's property *Work with the successor trustee(s) if the decedent had a living trust *Solicit beneficiaries' input on and consent to important decisions, such as selling assets or changing investments *Collect money owed to the estate - for example, final wages or insurance benefits *Pay bills and debts owed by the estate *Manage any legal issues related to the decedent's estate or assets *Prepare and file the decedent's final income tax returns, and if necessary, tax returns for the estate *Prepare and file [[#Estate_and_inheritance_tax|estate tax]] returns if necessary (or desirable as in the case of [https://www.schwab.com/learn/story/how-portability-helps-couples-reduce-estate-taxes portability] ) *Distribute assets to beneficiaries and close the estate
Executors have a fiduciary duty to the estate, meaning they are legally obligated to act in the estate's best interest. This duty precludes behaviors like personally benefiting from estate assets (or stealing them outright), distributing assets other than in accordance with the will or before the probate court gives permission, unfairly advantaging certain beneficiaries, and even making excessively risky investments.
Executors may be entitled to reasonable compensation for their time, which can make sense if the responsibilities are particularly time-consuming, or if the executor is not closely related to the decedent. However, compensation is taxable as income, so if the executor is also a beneficiary it could make more sense to decline compensation which results in a larger inheritance, which is tax-free absent estate taxes.
