A '''trust''' is a legal entity where assets are held, managed, and distributed by a trustee (or multiple trustees) for the benefit of a beneficiary. They are a common element of many [[Estate_planning|estate plans]].
Trusts are created either by drafting a trust agreement with the aid of an attorney, or created when a person dies with the parameters contained in their will; these are called [[Trusts#Testamentary Trusts|''testamentary trusts.'']] Trusts can be written with basically any terms, as long as the terms do not violate any laws. As a general rule, trusts become more important as your level of assets increase, although there are situations when trusts make sense even with limited assets. Trusts usually involve some expense to set up and to maintain, so this cost should be considered when deciding whether to create one – although in some cases the decision is obvious, for example, leaving assets to minor children, or spending thousands of dollars on a trust to avoid millions in [[Estate and inheritance tax|estate taxes]]. Your estate planning attorney should be able to consider your overall situation and advise you on areas where it may make sense to use trusts.
==Trust basics==
Trusts are extremely diverse in their purpose and construction, but all trusts have three entities:
*A ''grantor'' (sometimes called a ''settlor'') or grantors, who creates the trust and contributes assets into the trust *A ''trustee'' or trustees, who manage the assets of the trust and distribute them according to the terms of the trust *A ''beneficiary'' or beneficiaries, who receives distributions from the trust
In some cases, two or even all three of these roles may be filled by the same person. One important feature of trusts is whether they are ''revocable'' or ''irrevocable''. With a revocable trust, the grantor can take assets back out of the trust at any time, and/or change the terms of the trust. With an irrevocable trust, once the trust agreement is signed, the terms cannot be changed, and the assets cannot be removed except by the trustee in accordance with the terms of the trust. While irrevocable trusts eliminate flexibility for the grantor, they are necessary for certain purposes, such as asset protection and estate tax avoidance. Irrevocable trusts are considered separate entities for purposes of estate taxes, and this feature can be useful for estate tax avoidance.
Certain common types of trusts are created as revocable trusts, but become irrevocable after some triggering event, such as the grantor’s death. For example, if parents create a trust for a special needs child, the trust is typically revocable while the parents are alive, so that they have the flexibility to move assets in and out and change the terms. But once both parents die, the trust becomes irrevocable and the appointed trustee begins managing the trust for the benefit of the child.
==Common uses==
There are many different kinds of trusts with a wide variety of objectives, far too many to list here. But, here are some common uses:
*Assets left to minors should generally be left in trust, because a trustee will need to manage assets on their behalf until they reach the age of majority. *When leaving a large amount of assets to children, even if they have reached the age of majority, you may want to leave the assets in trust until they have proven their ability to responsibly manage a large portfolio. One common arrangement is to have a trustee distribute assets to adult children as-needed for basic living expenses and education, and then to also distribute assets in several large chunks until the children reach a certain age (for example, 35), at which time they either become the trustee or a co-trustee<ref group="note">Having the beneficiary become the sole trustee may undermine some or all of the benefits that leaving the assets in trust would try to achieve. Consult with your estate planning attorney about the benefits and risks of the beneficiary becoming a sole trustee vs. co-trustee.</ref> and gain some control of the trust, or the trust is dissolved with all remaining assets distributed directly to them. See [[#Leaving_assets_directly_vs._in_trust|below]]. However, many experienced estate planning attorneys recommend against significant restrictions on types of distributions, as well as against mandated distributions at particular beneficiary ages. As to restricting the purpose of distributions, unexpected life events may dictate more flexibility with future distributions. As to mandating age based distributions, an alternative is to leave the assets in the trust and allow the beneficiary greater control of the distributions by making the beneficiary trustee or co-trustee at a certain age.<ref group="note">Having a beneficiary as a trustee is a complex topic that requires the advice of qualified legal counsel. As a general rule, the more control or influence a beneficiary has over trust assets, the greater the risk that desired asset protections can diminish. Source: [https://leimbergservices.com/all/LISIMorrow3_9_2017.pdf Subject: Ed Morrow: Asset Protection Dangers When a Beneficiary Is Sole Trustee and Piercing the Third Party, Beneficiary- Controlled, Irrevocable Trust]</ref> This allows the beneficiary to maintain trust protections in the event of a messy divorce, third party claims or bankruptcy, eligibility for disability based government benefits, or other unexpected life events where trust protections may be useful. Depending on how the trust is structured, it may also avoid estate taxes on the child's eventual estate. *Some have used trusts to incentivize or disincentivize certain behavior from heirs - for example, paying for education only in a particular field, or paying for a wedding only when marrying a spouse of a certain religion. As long as these stipulations do not violate any laws, they are generally legal and enforceable by the trustee(s). However, use caution when attempting to control other people's behavior, especially from beyond the grave. Usually, the attempts at control will not be successful and will only create resentment. *Irrevocable trusts are commonly used for [[Estate_planning#Estate_tax_planning_and_avoidance|estate tax avoidance]] for those with a very large net worth. Investors who expect to pay estate taxes can gift the full estate tax exemption worth of assets into the trust, which is estate tax-free, although a [[gift tax]] return must be filed which uses up the investor's lifetime estate tax exemption. Then, because the trust is a separate legal entity, future growth within the trust is estate tax-free. Assets within the trust lose the [[step-up in basis]], and also face compressed trust tax brackets and the costs for maintaining the trust. But, for long periods of time and high growth, these can be far outweighed by saving the 40% estate tax. This strategy is also useful when you expect the statutory estate tax exemption to decrease, because it "locks in" the current exemption. *Trusts are often set up for the purpose of asset protection. A properly drafted and executed irrevocable trust segregates ownership of the funded assets from individual ownership, potentially protecting against creditors, lawsuits or divorcing spouses. *Trusts, whether revocable or irrevocable, are often used as a strategy to avoid the [[probate]] process. *Specific types of trusts can be created to facilitate qualification for government needs based benefits for individuals with special needs or in need of long-term care.
===Leaving assets directly vs. in trust===
It may be better to pass on taxable assets via a trust (which will almost always be an irrevocable trust or sub-trust) as opposed to directly to an individual via TOD or POD. Assets typically pass to such trusts either through the will (testamentary trusts) or as part of a [[#Revocable Living Trusts (RLTs)|Revocable Living Trust]]. The trust can be structured such that the beneficiary still maintains substantial control of the assets, or control can be reduced or eliminated in the case of a [[#Spendthrift trusts|spendthrift]] beneficiary. An analogous choice must be made when deciding whether to dissolve a trust left for children when they reach a certain age, or leave the trust intact, and possibly appoint them trustee and give them control of the trust.
Leaving assets in trust can have several advantages to the beneficiary. It provides increased protection against [[Asset protection|creditor claims]] and potential division in a divorce. Most states exclude inheritance from division in a divorce even if they are not inside a trust, but even if the heir does not live in a state where inheritances are divisible in divorce, there is a chance they could move to one later. Leaving assets in trust can also exclude them from spousal maintenance and child support obligation calculations. It also removes the assets from the heir's future estate, reducing their potential estate tax liability, if applicable. Even if the heir does not live in a state with a [[Estate_and_inheritance_tax#State_estate_and_inheritance_taxes|low state estate tax exemption]], there is a chance they could move to one later. Downsides of leaving assets via trust include the cost and complexity of creating and maintaining a trust, and the potential loss of [[step-up in basis]] for their eventual heirs.
==Specific trust types==
===Revocable Living Trusts (RLTs)===
[https://www.investopedia.com/terms/r/revocabletrust.asp Revocable living trusts] are multi-purpose trusts into which an individual or couple places their assets during their lifetime. They are usually set up to become irrevocable, or create irrevocable sub-trusts, when one or both spouses die. Advantages of Revocable Living Trusts include:
*They pass assets to heirs outside [[probate]]. Probate takes time and money, and the process and costs are state-specific. In certain states (such as California) probate avoidance can be a great benefit due to the extent of time and high costs involved with the probate process. Probate also creates a public record of your assets. Your estate planning attorney can advise on the value of avoiding probate for your situation. *They allow you great flexibility in specifying how assets will be distributed after you die - for example, creating sub-trusts for minor children, bypass trusts so that one spouse's assets will go somewhere other than to the surviving spouse, and so on. *They are useful in dealing with cases of incapacity, and in fact financial institutions may more easily accept a new trustee than a [[Estate_planning#Power_of_Attorney|Power of Attorney]]. A co-trustee or successor trustee may be able to step to manage applicable assets and accounts more smoothly than a named Power of Attorney. *There may be other state specific reasons for using a revocable living trust.<ref group="note">*Florida requires a personal representative to be either a relative or a Florida resident. If someone's first choice is neither a relative nor a Florida resident, a revocable trust is a workaround.
*In New York, if someone does not know who their nearest relatives are, or where they are, it is complicated. That sometimes happens, especially with Holocaust survivors.
*In Delaware, the court fee is 1.75% of the value of the probate assets, not counting the real estate.
*Different states have different ways of determining when a trust is taxable in that state. A revocable trust can sometimes avoid state income taxation in a decedent's home state}}</ref><ref>{{Forum link|title=Re: Corporate Trustee Recommendations|p=8479945|author=Bruce Steiner(estate planning attorney)|date=August 14, 2025}}</ref>
Downsides of a RLT include:
*There are costs to set up (usually several thousand dollars), and also to amend the trust whenever changes are necessary. *Assets should be retitled to place them inside the trust, which can be a substantial effort. Unfortunately, many people fail to do this, making the RLT much less useful. Alternatively the RLT could be a named beneficiary or contingent beneficiary, but in this case the co-trustee or successor trustee will lose the ability to manage assets via the RLT in the case of incapacity. The RLT can also be named as the beneficiary of a pour-over will, but this will require probating the will. *The [[#Trustees|trustee(s)]] may turn out not to be competent or may not act in good faith, requiring other parties to take legal action. They may not even know about the RLT and its contents. *Unless you are able pass all assets outside of probate, you will likely have to go through probate anyway, and in some states with easier probate the cost of probate is mostly fixed, regardless of the value of assets involved.<ref>{{Forum link|title=Re:Disclaimer trusts — am I missing something?|p=8474369|author=Poster Eric (estate planning attorney)|date=August 12, 2025}}</ref>
[https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/bypass_trust Bypass trusts] (sometimes called ''[https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/ab_trust A-B trusts]''), a type of revocable living trust, were once commonly used to transfer the unused portion of a spouse's federal estate exemption to the surviving spouse. The need for this feature reduced dramatically once the federal estate tax exemption became portable between spouses in 2012.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.tiaa.org/public/pdf/portability_provisions_and_their_impact_on_your_estate_plan.pdf| title=Portability provisions and their impact on an estate plan| publisher=TIAA| accessdate=June 15, 2024}}</ref> However, bypass trusts still have some uses - for example, some [[Estate_and_inheritance_tax#State_estate_and_inheritance_taxes|state estate taxes]] do not have a portable exemption between spouses, and there may be reasons why the first-to-die spouse may want to leave their assets other than directly to the surviving spouse.
===Spendthrift trusts===
[https://trustandwill.com/learn/spendthrift-trust Spendthrift trusts] can be used to leave money to someone who is thought to have an overspending problem. Usually, spendthrift trusts never fully distribute assets to the beneficiary. Versions of spendthrift trusts can be used for heirs with substance abuse issues or other addictions (for example, gambling), with terms to monitor spending, distribute assets only when the heir is in active treatment, and so on.
Spendthrift trusts contain spendthrift provisions that articulate the conditions in which the trustee can disburse funds.
===Special Needs Trusts (SNTs)===
[https://www.specialneedsalliance.org/the-voice/your-special-needs-trust-snt-defined-2/ Special Needs Trusts] (SNTs) have the purpose of holding assets for the future care of someone with special needs or disabilities, while preserving their eligibility for needs-based benefits, such as Medicaid or Supplemental Security Income (SSI).<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.fidelity.com/learning-center/life-events/what-is-special-needs-trust| title=What is a special needs trust?| publisher=Fidelity| accessdate=January 13, 2025}}</ref> This type of trust must conform with specific requirements. SNTs are usually either ''first-party,'' meaning they are funded with assets the beneficiary already owns (possibly by way of a settlement or inheritance), or ''third-party'' (also known as a ''[[Planning for disabled adult children#Supplemental Needs Trusts|Supplemental Needs Trust]]''<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.bmcestateplanning.com/blog/differences-between-supplemental-needs-trust-special-needs-trust| title=4 Differences Between a Supplemental Needs Trust and a Special Needs Trust| publisher=Borenstein McConnell & Calpin| accessdate=January 13, 2025}}</ref>), meaning they are funded with the grantor's assets. SNTs have specific requirements, such as:
*The beneficiary of a first-party SNT must have a documented disability recognized by the Social Security Administration. Whether this is true for a third-party SNT is dependent upon the applicable state. *First-party SNTs must be funded before the beneficiary reaches age 65, and no further assets can be transferred into the trust once the beneficiary reaches this age. The trust can remain established and provide benefits regardless of the beneficiary's age. *SNTs generally should not provide cash or cash-like benefits to the beneficiary, as doing so may reduce or eliminate the applicable government assistance. They should only pay for supplemental needs (qualified disability expenses, excluding housing and food) as established in the trust agreement. *When the beneficiary of a first-party SNT dies, the trust is required to reimburse the government (to the extent possible) for medical expenses paid on the beneficiary's behalf. Third-party SNTs do not have this requirement.
SNTs are complex and there are specific legal requirements. If you are considering a SNT, be sure to consult with an estate planning attorney who has experience with this type of trust.
SNTs also often qualify as a [https://www.specialneedsalliance.org/the-voice/is-a-qualified-disability-trust-appropriate-2/ Qualified Disability Trust] (QDisT). This type of trust allows additional tax benefits such as a tax exemption for income retained in the trust. The 2025 exemption is $5,100.
===Asset protection trusts=== {{Main|Asset protection}}
[[Asset_protection#Complex_asset_protection_strategies|Asset protection trusts]] come in many designs, but are all designed to move your assets from your name into a trust's name, making it harder for a creditor to collect them, while still giving you an acceptable level of access. Generally, asset protection trusts are expensive and do not provide ironclad protection, and so are only appropriate for limited situations, and even then only after more standard tools (such as [[umbrella insurance]]) are in place first.
===Medicaid Asset Protection Trusts=== [https://www.medicaidplanningassistance.org/asset-protection-trusts/amp/ Medicaid Asset Protection Trusts] (MAPTs) are irrevocable trusts used to help individuals qualify for Medicaid funded long term care who would otherwise not qualify due to Medicaid means based asset tests. Assets in a properly drafted and funded MAPT will not count towards the Medicaid asset limit (typically $2,000). California eliminated Medicaid asset limits on January 1, 2024.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://cahealthadvocates.org/medi-cals-asset-limit-is-now-eliminated/| title=Medi-Cal's Asset Limit is Now Eliminated| publisher=California Health Advocates| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref>
Medicaid is administered by the states, the result being that rules can vary by state. There are various restrictions and limitations that can come into play. For instance, there are typically look-back periods,<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.medicaidplanningassistance.org/medicaid-look-back-period/| title=How the Medicaid Look-Back Period Works| publisher=Americal Council on Aging| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref> often (but not always) 60 months, such that personal funds directed into the MAPT within the prior 5 year period can disqualify you from Medicaid eligibility.
With MAPTs neither the trust grantor (creator) nor the grantors spouse can be the trustee. An adult child or other relative can be the trustee. MAPT funds cannot be used for the benefit of the trustee. Additionally, a beneficiary is set up who will benefit from the trust once the grantor dies. The beneficiary cannot be the grantor. After the death of the grantor Medicaid cannot claw back funds from a properly drafted and funded MAPT.
===Irrevocable Life Insurance Trusts (ILITs)===
Irrevocable life insurance trusts (ILITs) are a way to leave a guaranteed amount of money estate tax-free to an heir. You create an ILIT by purchasing a permanent life insurance policy inside an irrevocable trust, and funding it with annual premiums that are within the annual gift exclusion ($19,000 as of 2025). The policy should be chosen to maximize the death benefit for the given premium, and other features of the policy (for example, non-direct recognition and wash loans) are of little to no importance. The fully tax-deferred growth of a permanent life insurance policy is an advantage inside a trust because of the [[#Taxes_in_trusts|compressed trust tax brackets]]. However, any asset can be purchased inside an irrevocable trust, and over a long time horizon, high-growth assets like [[Stock basics|stock]]-based [[Mutual fund|mutual funds]] invested [[Tax-efficient fund placement|tax-efficiently]] will likely outperform a life insurance policy. Even a term life insurance policy can be purchased inside a trust. For these reasons, ILITs are most appropriate where there is a need to leave a ''guaranteed'' amount of money in the trust (for example, if there will be a known estate tax bill due), even at the expense of likely lower returns.
===Spousal Lifetime Access Trusts (SLATs)===
A Spousal Lifetime Access Trust (SLAT) is a type of irrevocable trust designed to remove assets from a couple's eventual estate, for the purpose of avoiding estate taxes, while still giving one spouse (and indirectly, the other spouse too) some level of access to the assets during their lifetimes. A SLAT is structured as a gift from one spouse (the donor spouse) to the other (beneficiary spouse), typically up to the current federal estate tax exemption. Any further growth on the trust assets occurs inside the trust, where it will not be subject to eventual estate taxes. The beneficiary spouse can draw on trust assets (typically for health, education, maintenance, and support), but access is not unlimited, so couples should not commit assets they want to spend most of. A SLAT is often set up as an [https://www.fidelity.com/viewpoints/wealth-management/insights/intentionally-defective-grantor-trusts Intentionally Defective Grantor Trust] (IDGT), such that the grantor pays the income tax out of the grantor’s assets, lowering the eventual estate and increasing the growth of the trust assets. SLATS must deal with contingencies such as divorce and various beneficiary arrangements, and are complex and expensive to set up, but could be worth millions of dollars in avoided estate taxes.
===Marital trusts===
Also referred to as marital deduction trusts or spousal trusts, [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/marital-trust.asp marital trusts] are trusts that are funded upon the death of a spouse for the benefit of the surviving spouse. The trust income and in some cases the trust principal can be used to support the surviving spouse. In addition to typical irrevocable trust benefits such as asset protection and future probate avoidance, in some cases these trusts are also used to defer or reduce estate taxes. In cases where the estate amount exceeds estate tax thresholds they may be used in conjunction with a [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/creditsheltertrust.asp credit shelter trust] (also referred to as a [https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/bypass_trust bypass] or [https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/ab_trust A/B trust]<ref>[https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/credit_shelter_trust Cornell Law - Credit Shelter Trust]</ref>).
With the higher federal estate tax thresholds of more recent years, as well as [https://www.schwab.com/learn/story/how-portability-helps-couples-reduce-estate-taxes portability], these trusts may not be as useful as they used to be.
===Disclaimer Trusts===
A [https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/disclaimer_trust disclaimer trust] is another type of trust used to reduce estate taxes. Unlike a [https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/credit_shelter_trust Credit Shelter] / Bypass trust the disclaimer trust gives the surviving spouse optionality upon the decedent spouse’s death to choose whether to fund the trust and if so how much. This can be useful since a couple’s future net worth can’t be predicted plus estate tax thresholds frequently change. While the federal estate tax threshold is very high, some states have estate tax thresholds that are considerably lower, making the election optionality more useful. However, a discretionary trust does limit the flexibility of the inheriting spouse in terms of controlling distributions from the trust.<ref>[https://www.fidelity.com/viewpoints/wealth-management/insights/marital-disclaimer-trusts Marital disclaimer trusts]</ref> One strategy may be for couples likely to hit the estate tax threshold to use a credit shelter trust due to its increased flexibility of future distributions. For couples that aren’t as likely to hit the threshold, but would still like the estate tax protection if the limits were to decrease in the future, a discretionary trust may make more sense.<ref>{{Forum link|title=Re:Disclaimer trusts — am I missing something?|p=8473438|author=Bruce Steiner|date=August 12, 2025}}</ref>.
The [https://www.geigerlawoffice.com/blog/what-is-a-clayton-election-trust-.cfm Clayton election] is an alternative to a disclaimer trust that can give the surviving spouse trustee more flexibility in controlling distributions plus allow a 15 month distribution vs 9 months election period for a discretionary trust.<ref>{{Forum link|title=Re:Disclaimer trusts — am I missing something?|p=8476579|author=Bruce Steiner|date=August 12, 2025}}</ref> <ref>[https://hjlawfirm.com/marital-disclaimers-and-the-clayton-election-last-minute-estate-tax-planning/ Clayton Election]</ref>
===Generation Skipping Trusts===
Trusts established to pass assets to grandchildren while allowing children to potentially access income generated from those assets tax-free are referred to as [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/g/generation-skippingtrust.asp generation skipping trusts.] A generation skipping trust reduces the amount of estate taxes when high net worth individuals pass down their wealth. Generation skipping transfers go directly to grandchildren or great-grandchildren and are only taxed once instead of being taxed at each generation of inheritance.
In response to this type of estate tax avoidance strategy a [https://www.fidelity.com/viewpoints/wealth-management/insights/generation-skipping-transfer-tax generation skipping transfer tax] was created. The federal threshold amounts are currently equal to the federal estate tax thresholds. This type of tax only comes into play for very large estates.
===Intentionally Defective Grantor Trusts (IDGTs)===
An [https://www.fidelity.com/viewpoints/wealth-management/insights/intentionally-defective-grantor-trusts Intentionally Defective Grantor Trust] (IDGT) is a type of irrevocable trust commonly used to remove assets from a person's eventual estate, for the purpose of avoiding estate taxes. The beneficiaries can be anyone, but is most commonly children. IDGTs are intentionally structured such that the grantor is responsible for paying the income taxes on any taxable growth of trust assets, not the trust itself. This feature allows the trust assets to grow faster, as the grantor is able to effectively contribute the taxes owed to the trust each year without triggering additional gift taxes. A secondary benefit of an IDGT is that individual tax rates of the grantor may very well be less than the compressed income tax rates of a trust. IDGTs are complex and expensive to set up, but may be well worth the effort in avoided estate tax.
===Crummey trusts===
A ''Crummey trust'' is a trust that has the feature of a ''Crummey provision'' or ''Crummey power.'' Many types of trusts can have this provision, although they are commonly used by wealthy individuals to provide assets in trust for their children. The federal annual [[gift tax]] exclusion ($19,000 as of 2025) only applies to gifts of ''present interest'', meaning that the recipient has immediate access to the gift. Contributions into a trust to which the beneficiary only has future access do not qualify for the exclusion, and therefore the entire amount of the gift is subject to [[gift tax]]. A Crummey provision is a trust provision that allows the trust beneficiary a limited window of time (for example, 30 days) to take immediate possession of a trust contribution. The beneficiary is only allowed to take immediate possession of the current contribution (which is usually no greater than the annual gift exclusion), not the entirety of trust assets. If the beneficiary takes no action to take control of the contribution, it automatically becomes property of the trust and subject to the trust's distribution terms. Because the beneficiary had an opportunity to withdraw the funds, the gift is deemed to be a present interest and therefore is entitled to an annual gift exclusion.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/crummey-trust.asp| title=Crummey Trust: Definition, Purpose, How It Works, and History| publisher=Investopedia| accessdate=January 13, 2025}}</ref>
Usually the trust grantor does not want the beneficiary to exercise their right to withdraw the gift immediately; otherwise, they would simply give the gift directly and avoid the cost and hassle of the trust. Therefore, the grantor typically either implicitly or explicitly makes future contributions predicated on the beneficiary ''not'' withdrawing the current gift. This condition may even be written into the trust agreement.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://smartasset.com/financial-advisor/crummey-trust| title=Understanding Crummey Trusts and How to Use Them| publisher=smartasset| accessdate=January 13, 2025}}</ref>
===Charitable Remainder Trusts (CRTs)=== {{Main|Charitable remainder trust}}
A Charitable Remainder Trust (CRT) is a type of irrevocable trust that is set up to make regular payments to a beneficiary for some term specified by the trust, and at the end of the term or after the death of the last beneficiary, remaining trust assets are distributed to a charity. They can be further divided into Charitable Remainder Annuity Trusts (CRATs) and Charitable Remainder Unitrusts (CRUTs). See the main page for more details. CRTs may also be useful in tax-planning when you expect to pass on [[Stretch_IRA#Post-SECURE_Act_strategies_for_owners|large pre-tax IRAs to heirs]].
===Charitable Lead Trusts (CLTs)=== {{Main|Charitable lead trust}}
A Charitable Lead Trust (CLT) is a type of irrevocable trust that is set up to make regular payments to a charity or charities for some term specified by the trust, and at the end of the term trust assets are distributed either back to the grantor or to another beneficiary. They are less common than Charitable Remainder Trusts.
===Inherited IRA trusts===
In cases where [[Inheriting an IRA|inherited IRAs]] are left in trust, additional care is required in creating the trust such that the IRA will retain the full applicable [[Required Minimum Distribution|RMD]] period/stretch available to the beneficiary, vs reverting to a five year default IRA distribution period applicable to non person entities (non-designated beneficiaries<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.morningstar.com/retirement/inherited-ira-rules-what-you-need-know-before-2025| title=IRA rules you need to know| publisher=Morningstar| date=October 11, 2024| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref>), such as trusts, charities or estates. Trusts that qualify for the extended [[Required Minimum Distribution|RMD]] period available to the beneficiary must be [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/s/seethrough-trust.asp#:~:text=A%20see%2Dthrough%20trust%20is,the%20account%20after%20their%20death. see-through trusts]. The two most common types of inherited IRA see through trusts are [https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/accumulation_trust#:~:text=Accumulation%20trust%20is%20a%20type,or%20kept%20within%20the%20trust%20. accumulation trusts] and conduit trusts.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://ataxplan.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/Estate-Planning-for-Retirement-Benefits-2024-4.pdf| author=Natalie Choate| title=Estate Planning for Retirement Benefits 2024-04| pages=52-54| publisher=Ataxplan| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref>
With a conduit trust, RMDs must be distributed from the trust. Prior to the [https://www.investopedia.com/secure-act-4688468 Secure Act], when lifetimes stretches were available to most inherited IRAs, some perceived a conduit trust as simpler and safer with regards to IRS acceptance and see-through status, especially if the IRA balances and annual RMDs were modest. However, with the [https://www.investopedia.com/secure-act-4688468 Secure Act], the distribution for most non spouse inherited IRAs decreased to ten years, which in some cases has resulted in [https://www.kitces.com/blog/secure-act-see-through-conduit-trust-stretch-ira-10-year-non-eligible-designated-beneficiary/ complications] for conduit trusts. Accumulation trusts (sometimes referred to as discretionary trusts) allow the trustee to choose whether to distribute the RMD to the beneficiary or to maintain the RMD within the trust. This flexibility is useful if creditor protection is a concern,<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.aaepa.com/2016/01/9893-2/| title=Conduit or Accumulation Trust| publisher=American Academy of Estate Planning Attorneys| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref> or in the case of special needs trusts where mandatory distributions can be problematic for some types of government benefit eligibility.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.specialneedsalliance.org/the-voice/naming-a-special-needs-trust-as-beneficiary-of-your-ira-or-retirement-plan-3/| title=Naming a Special Needs Trust as Beneficiary of Your IRA or Retirement Plan| publisher=Special Needs Alliance| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref> As such in most cases an accumulation trust is considered superior to a conduit trust for inherited IRAs,<ref>{{cite web| url=https://new.leimbergservices.com/all/LISISteinerPDF12_23_2019.pdf| title=Bruce Steiner & Planning Under the SECURE Act| publisher=Leimberg Information Services| date=December 23, 2019| accessdate=June 7, 2025}}</ref> except in the case of surviving spouses, where the Secure Act 2.0 allowed the use of the longer extended uniform life expectancy RMD table in the case of IRAs left in conduit trusts to spouses.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://ultimateestateplanner.com/secure-act-2-0-offers-longer-stretch-for-conduit-trusts-but-contains-traps-for-surviving-spouses/| title=SECURE Act 2.0 Offers Longer Stretch for Conduit Trusts, But Contains Traps for Surviving Spouses| publisher=Ultimate Estate Planner, Inc.| accessdate=September 24, 2025}}</ref>
===Testamentary Trusts===
A [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/testamentarytrust.asp testamentary trust] is established through the instructions of a last will and testament and becomes irrevocable upon the owner’s death. The trust is not created until after the owner’s death. Testamentary trusts may be used if the trust creator wishes to avoid the hassle and cost of creating a revocable living trust. Since they are established through the will, the funds must first go through the [[probate]] process.
===Family Trusts===
A [https://www.legalzoom.com/articles/what-is-a-family-trust family trust] is a generic or colloquial term, without specific legal meaning, to describe various types of trusts used to accommodate and benefit family interests. They can be revocable or irrevocable. They encompass many of the broad objectives of trusts, such as estate tax avoidance, asset protection and probate avoidance.<ref>[https://smartasset.com/financial-advisor/family-trust What Is a Family Trust, and How Do You Set One Up?]</ref>
==Trustees==
If your estate plan includes trusts, you will need to nominate a trustee, or multiple trustees, to manage and distribute assets per the trust agreement. In some cases, this trustee can be a qualified family member. The trust can even permit the trustee to receive some compensation for their time. A family member trustee has the advantage that they may know the beneficiary well, and will understand their needs and behaviors better than most people. In the case of minor children, it may or may not make sense to have the guardian be the trustee of the child’s assets; probably not if the guardian is great with kids but not good managing money. Co-trustees can also be nominated, for example, one person from each side of the children’s family (sometimes referred to an A-list/B-list arrangement).
A Successor Trustee is the person responsible for administering the trust after its Grantor either passes away, becomes incapacitated or otherwise unable to serve. The grantor (trust creator) designates the successor trustee and the successor trustee’s responsibilities in the original trust document.
Trustees have certain limitations which may affect your decision of who to nominate for each role. Refer to the following table.
{| class="wikitable" |+ Trustee limitations |- ! '''Trustee''' !! '''Notes and limitations''' |- | Beneficiary || * A beneficiary can create conflicts of interest if multiple beneficiaries are involved. * A sole trustee cannot be the sole beneficiary. This would be considered an illegitimate trust. * Can diminish asset protections against creditors and lawsuits. Generally, the more control beneficiary has over trust assets the less asset protection is afforded. |- | Grantor || * An irrevocable trust where the grantor is also the beneficiary is referred to as a Domestic Asset Protection Trust or DAPT. The grantor is allowed to be the beneficiary of the trust, but it has to be created in one of the 20 jurisdictions where the grantor is allowed to be the beneficiary. |- | Friend or relative || * If the trustee fails to follow terms of trust or embezzles trust assets, there is often no recourse except lawsuit; lawsuits are often long and costly and the misbehaving trustee can often deplete trust assets to defend himself. * If the <nowiki>*beneficiary*</nowiki> appoints a close relative or employee as a trustee, it may invalidate some of the asset protections. If the grantor appointed the beneficiary's relative or employee, there is no such risk. |}
As an alternative to family trustees, a [https://trustandwill.com/learn/professional-trustee/ professional trustee] may be engaged to manage the trust. Professional trustees typically have a fiduciary responsibility. Professional trustees include banks and financial institutions, also referred to as [https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/corporate_trustee corporate trustees], that have trust departments with professional trustees who can be hired to manage trusts. Professional trustees also include law firms and individual professionals, such as attorneys or accountants<ref>[https://www.legalzoom.com/articles/what-does-a-trustee-do#:~:text=resources%20for%20themselves.-,2.,attention%20that%20some%20trusts%20require. Legal Zoom - What is a Trustee and What do They do?]</ref>. Advantages of a professional trustee include that the trustee is very experienced with trusts and with managing assets. <ref>[https://trustandwill.com/learn/professional-trustee/ Trust & Will: Benefits of Hiring a Professional Trustee]</ref>It could also be an advantage if they are able to follow the terms of the trust more dispassionately than a family member would. If you nominate a professional trustee, choose one with experience managing the type of trusts and assets you will be leaving behind. The major downside of a professional trustee is the cost, which can be significant – usually something like 1%/year or more of trust assets. These firms typically have sliding fee scales, such that the percent of assets fee goes down as the size of the managed trust assets increases. Professional trustees can also sometimes be viewed by some as inflexible or overly conservative. Consider whether having ''both'' family and professional co-trustees could be best, as the advantages of one might make up for the shortcomings of the other. Alternatively, the existence of a trust committee or trust protector to oversee the performance of the corporate trustee can provide an additional level of accountability.
Trustees may or may not be inclined to follow [[Bogleheads®_investment_philosophy|Bogleheads investing principles]] of minimizing investment fees and avoiding stock-picking; you should ask about this when interviewing trustees. Bear in mind that the trustee may not take over for many decades, and the trust may last for decades after that, so the person you’re interviewing might be retired for some or all of the trustee’s tenure. In that case, someone else from their firm (who may not even be born yet) will act as trustee. One approach to address this would be writing your investing philosophy into the terms of the trust. However if the terms of the trust are viewed as too inflexible the corporate trustee may choose not to serve.<ref>[https://www.kiplinger.com/retirement/choosing-a-corporate-trustee-pros-and-cons Kiplinger - Choosing a Corporate Trustee: The Pros and Cons]</ref> Another approach would be to document your preferences in a supplemental “[https://www.bessemertrust.com/insights/sharing-your-vision-and-values-exploring-letters-of-wishes letter of wishes]”. This document is not legally binding, but does give guidance and context to the trustee but allows the trustee more flexibility in accomplishing the stated preferences.
Those who would prefer the hired trustee to be limited to the administrative aspects of managing the trust, but not the investing or distribution decisions, a [https://commonwealth-trust.com/directed-trusts-vs-delegated-trusts-what-is-the-difference/ directed trustee] may be an option. A Directed Trustee may handle administrative tasks relating to the Trust agreement, accounting duties, distribution of funds or income, and other ministerial functions<ref>[https://trustandwill.com/learn/directed-trustee/ Trust&will-Directed Trustee: What Does a Directed Trustee Do?]</ref>. A Directed Trustee does not make investment decisions regarding the trust. A Directed Trustee may charge approximately half of what a corporate trustee would.<ref>[https://www.wealthadvisorstrust.com/trustee-fee-schedule/directed-trust-trustee-fees Wealth Advisors Trust - Simple explanation of a Directed Trust and Directed trust fee schedule]</ref> Specific states have differing laws surrounding directed trustees, affecting their flexibility, form and liability.<ref>[https://www.actec.org/overview-of-state-directed-trust-statutes/ ACTEC - Overview of State Directed Trust Statutes]</ref> Directed Trustees tend to be more common in asset protection states. <ref>{{Forum link|title= Re: looking for a directed trustee whose fees are based on tasks performed|p= 8496327|author=Bruce Steiner (estate planning attorney)|date=August 28, 2025}}</ref>
Trusts have no automatic enforcement mechanism to make sure that the trustee follows the terms of the trust. If the trustee violates the trust agreement, the remedy is generally legal action. So, be especially sure you trust the trustee to fulfill their role for a long period of time. As mentioned above, the existence of a trust committee or trust protector can provide an additional level of oversight.
==Taxes in trusts==
Generally, income from revocable trusts is taxable on the grantor’s tax return as though the assets were owned by them directly with no trust. In this case, assets are titled using the trust’s name and the grantor’s Social Security Number. Irrevocable trusts may be considered ''grantor trusts'', meaning trust income is also taxable directly by the grantor, or ''non-grantor trusts'', meaning income is taxable at the trust level.
Non-grantor trusts have their own EIN, and must file their own income tax returns and pay tax according to the trust brackets. The trust bracket scale is similar to those for individual taxpayers, but is highly compressed – as of 2025, the maximum 37% tax rate is reached with just $15,650 of income<ref>{{cite web| url=https://smartasset.com/taxes/trust-tax-rates| title=Trust Tax Rates and Exemptions for 2024 and 2025| publisher=SmartAsset| accessdate=January 2, 2025}}</ref> (and trusts get no standard deduction, although there is an income threshold of $100 for needing to file a trust tax return).<ref group="note">An exception is a Qualified Disability Trust (QDisT), a specific type of supplemental needs trust, which allows an additional tax exemption for income retained in the trust. The 2025 exemption is $5,100.</ref> Distributions from a trust (reported to beneficiaries on a [https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f1041sk1.pdf Form 1041 Schedule K-1]) are deductible against trust income but taxable to the beneficiary at their own marginal rate. This usually<ref group="note>If the beneficiary is in the top (37%) tax bracket themselves based on other income, leaving income within the trust is actually a small tax advantage, as $15,650 will be taxed at a lower rate.</ref> creates a tax incentive for the trustee to distribute assets from the trust each year, up to the amount of taxable income from trust assets. Tax benefits of distributions must be weighed against the loss of trust protections on that money. For the same reason, [[Tax-efficient_fund_placement|tax-efficient]] investing inside non-grantor trusts is even more important than otherwise. Trust-related expenses, which could include trust tax preparation fees and some (but not all) corporate trustee fees, are deductible on the trust tax return.
In such cases where the income of the trust to be distributed will not be known until late in the year or the following year, the trustees can elect the 65 day election. The 65-day election is designed for situations like this where the trustees may not know the amount of income until after the end of the year. It's in [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/663 Internal Revenue Code Section 663(b)]. The trustees may elect to treat distributions made during the first 65 days after the end of the year as if they were made on the last day of the previous year. <ref>{{Forum link|title=Re: Question on trust taxes and calendar year timing |p=8478172|author=Bruce Steiner|date=August 13, 2025}}.</ref>
To the extent IRAs are left in trust (preferably in a see-through accumulation trust) completing Roth conversions prior to original owner’s death can reduce future taxes on funds retained in the trust, allowing for more flexibility of distribution. Conversely, if an EDB (eligible designated beneficiary) with low income receives traditional IRAs in trust, they can receive a lifetime stretch and minimize taxes by distributing comparatively small amounts of annual RMD income to beneficiary at a lower tax rate than the original owner.
The rules for state taxation of trust income are complicated, so work with your estate planning attorney to determine if there are opportunities for state income tax saving through smart planning.

When '''facing the end of life''' (perhaps due to age, medical condition, or other reasons), this article describes prudent steps investors can take to improve their financial picture while still alive, have their wishes best-reflected after they're gone, and streamline and maximize the value of their estate for their heirs.
Although other aspects of the end of life - medical, family and interpersonal, spiritual, etc. - are probably more important and deserve primary attention, this article focuses on the financial aspect, and is intended as a concise guide on the financial steps to consider.
This article is intended for those who have a life expectancy of roughly five years or less, though some of the advice applies to other situations as well.
==Summary==
*Put an appropriate [[Estate planning|estate plan]] in place. *Make sure all [[Estate_planning#Designated_beneficiaries|beneficiaries]] are up-to-date and consistent with the estate plan. *Simplify and automate finances as much as practical. *Document all assets, including valuable physical property. *Avoid selling appreciated taxable assets on which capital gains tax would be owed; they will get a [[step-up in basis]]. *[[Roth conversion|Convert]] pre-tax retirement money to Roth as long as the [[marginal tax rate]] on the conversion is less than your heirs' expected marginal tax rate, while accounting for expected deductible medical expenses and charitable bequests. *Take qualified [[Health savings account|Health Savings Account (HSA)]] withdrawals for expenses for which you have saved receipts, if the HSA is being left to a non-spouse. *If you will likely face federal or state [[Estate and inheritance tax|estate taxes]], give money away to heirs, up to the annual [[gift tax]] exclusion.
==Estate planning== {{Main|Estate planning}}
When facing the end of life, a top financial priority is to put in place a comprehensive estate plan, or make sure an existing plan is up-to-date with the present circumstances. A good estate plan will ensure your wishes are reflected both before and after your death, and also streamline the estate process and maximize the value of your bequest for your heirs. Most estate laws are state-specific, and in almost all cases, it is essential to consult an estate planning attorney in your state. Below are the main areas of estate planning and the steps to consider.
===Major estate plan elements===
Make sure all the other elements of an [[Estate planning|estate plan]] are in place, if they apply to your situation, such as:
*Both a financial and medical Power of Attorney (POA) *Advance healthcare directive *Guardians for minor children *Will *Appropriate designated beneficiaries *Appropriate [[Trusts|trusts]] *[[Estate planning#Letter of instruction|Letter of instruction]]<ref>{{forum link| t=198919| author=[[Taylor Larimore]]| title=Letter of Final Instructions| date=September 5, 2016}}.</ref>
If you already have these elements in place, review them carefully to make sure everything is up-to-date, and make any appropriate changes.
===Estate taxes=== {{Main|Estate and inheritance tax}}
As of 2025, the federal estate tax exemption is $13.99 million for a single individual, and $27.98 million for a married couple. Due to this high limit, only a small percentage of taxpayers will owe federal estate tax. Some states also have an estate tax, and several have lower exemptions, as low as $1 million. For those who will possibly or likely owe estate tax, additional planning is necessary. See: [[Estate_planning#Estate_tax_planning_and_avoidance|Estate tax planning and avoidance]].
==Simplify and document finances==
While it is always a good idea to keep your financial life as simple as possible, it is especially important when dealing with medical issues or facing the end of your life. You will want to free up the maximum amount of time to be devoted toward your health, family, and other matters. Others will need to take over your finances after your death, and possibly before as well. Consider the following:
*Automate as much as possible. Set bills on auto-pay and payments on direct deposit. *Keep plenty of cash in your checking account to minimize the need to transfer money in/out between savings and investing accounts. *Consolidate accounts to the minimum number necessary, for example, by combining several like-kind accounts (for example, savings, brokerage) into one, canceling all but one or two credit cards, rolling out money from a former employer's 401k into an IRA, and paying off small debts. *Simplify investments as much as practical without realizing capital gains, for example, by consolidating several similar mutual funds into one, trading a set of individual stocks for a single [[mutual fund]], etc. Even if you enjoy managing money or even trading stocks as a hobby, your priorities will likely shift, and even if you still have interest in these activities now, your agents probably will not. *Compile a list of accounts, assets, and debts, including name of the custodian, account number, and approximate value.
If you will be leaving behind a spouse who will have to take over management of the family finances, additional planning is probably necessary. Carefully consider what financial services your family will need, keeping in mind that they will probably have other priorities and dealing with strong emotions after your death. If you are able, it is a great idea to work with your spouse and interview [[Financial planner|financial planners]], accountants, and any other financial professionals your family may need. This will help your spouse find the appropriate level of assistance for their situation. It may even make sense to have these professionals begin help while you are alive, so they can gain experience with your family and you can gain confidence in them while you are alive. See: [[Estate_planning#Continuity_of_financial_management|Continuity of financial management]].
==Budget==
Everyone needs a budget, even those facing the end of their life. But, your budget may change dramatically from what it was before. You may lose income due to stopping work, but you may also be able to claim certain benefits, such as disability pay. Certain expenses (for example, medical expenses) may grow dramatically, while others (for example, travel or other activities) may decrease or disappear completely. Due to a shorter life expectancy, you may be able to spend at a higher rate than you were before.
Especially for those accustomed to living frugally, delaying gratification, and saving a large percentage of their income, adjusting to a new budget may be difficult. Unless there is a real need to save heavily (for example, you are the family breadwinner with young children and you do not have sufficient life insurance), you should feel free to spend your money on what you value the most. Now is not the time to defer doing things that are important to you, such as traveling or starting a new hobby (assuming you have the physical and mental capability). The habit of saving can be difficult to break, and heavy spending especially if taken suddenly may have the opposite of the intended effect. If this is a potential issue for you, ease into spending gradually and see how it makes you feel before increasing further.
==Assets==
In general, when facing the end of your life, you should switch your investment plan from investing for your own life, to that of your heirs. For example, if you are a retiree with a conservative portfolio heavy in bonds, but your heirs are much younger with decades to retirement and stock-heavy portfolios, you should switch your [[asset allocation]] to more closely align with theirs. Be sure to retain enough funds in lower-risk liquid investments to cover expected expenses such as medical and assisted living. You should also adjust your investing behavior to account for the tax implications of having a short life expectancy, such as avoiding realizing capital gains that will not be taxed after your death due to the [[step-up in basis]]. The article on [[retirement draw-down priority]] contains [[Retirement_draw-down_priority#Tapping_taxable_investments_or_retirement_accounts|tables]] and a tool to determine which assets should be spent first, given your tax rate, your heir's tax rate, and your life expectancy.
It is generally not a benefit for tax savings or estate planning purposes to give assets away during your lifetime (with the one major exception of [[Estate_planning#Estate_tax_planning_and_avoidance|estate tax avoidance]] you're likely to pay estate tax because of a high net worth), or to add others as [[Asset_titling_in_the_United_States|joint owners]] on your assets. These maneuvers can actually cost taxes if you lose the [[step-up in basis]] and can complicate the settlement of your estate. See: [[Estate_planning#Gifting_and_titling|Gifting and titling]].
===Taxable assets=== {{Main|Taxable account}}
Upon the owner's death, taxable assets (assets held outside tax-advantaged accounts) get a [[Step-up in basis|step-up in basis]], meaning that the ''basis'' (sometimes called the ''cost basis'') of the asset, on which capital gains taxes are calculated, gets set to the market value of the asset on the date of the owner's death. This can be very valuable for assets with large unrealized gains. As such, it is usually best to avoid selling appreciated assets near the end of your life, even if they are not ideal - for example, individual stocks, actively managed mutual funds, real estate you no longer wish to own, etc. If you need to access the value of the asset, it is usually better to borrow against it, for example with a margin loan or Home Equity Line of Credit, than to sell the asset and incur the capital gains tax. Your estate or heirs can pay the loan off by selling the asset after it gets the step-up in basis.
The step-up in basis can also be a step-down in basis, if the basis is more than the current market value. If you own assets that are worth less than their basis, it is usually best to sell them and use the losses to offset other gains. See: [[Tax loss harvesting]].
Capital loss carryovers are lost at death, so if you have carryover losses, you can realize gains up to that amount for no net tax cost compared to not realizing the gains. This could be useful, for example, to restructure taxable investments or to liquidate investments to raise needed cash.
===Real estate===
Real estate gets a [[Step-up in basis|step-up in basis]] like other taxable assets (assuming it is owned outside tax-advantaged accounts), and you should similarly avoid realizing capital gains on real estate. Under current tax law, a primary residence gets up to a $250,000 (single) or $500,000 (married) capital gains exclusion, so this can reduce or eliminate the value of the step-up in basis for this asset.
===Retirement accounts===
Retirement accounts come in many forms - [[IRA]]s, [[401(k)]]s, [[403(b)]]s, [[457(b)]]s, and others, and most of these are available in pre-tax (also called "traditional" or "tax-deferred") or Roth tax structures. Retirement account tax planning strategies focus on when to make [[Traditional versus Roth|pre-tax vs. Roth contributions]], and when to do [[Roth IRA conversion|Roth conversions]], usually based on a comparison of current [[Marginal tax rate|marginal tax rate]] to predicted future marginal tax rate at withdrawal. When facing the end of life, the strategies shift to comparing to ''heirs''' predicted future marginal tax rates. Following the passage of the SECURE Act in 2019, [[Stretch_IRA#SECURE_Act_inherited_IRAs|most]] non-spouse heirs get 10 or 11 years to withdraw funds, so an ideal tax strategy would consider all heirs' expected tax situations within this time period after your death. See [[Stretch_IRA#Post-SECURE_Act_strategies_for_owners|Post-SECURE Act strategies for owners]] for a list of tax-planning strategies.
====Roth conversions==== {{Main|Roth conversion}}
Roth conversions can be a powerful planning tool for end-of-life tax planning. If you can convert pre-tax money to Roth at a lower rate than you expect your heirs to withdraw the money, it will increase the after-tax value of your bequest. Consider also that the SECURE Act requires non-spouse heirs to distribute retirement accounts within 10 or 11 years, so leaving a large pre-tax account ''per heir'' can raise their marginal tax rate much higher than it is now.
For example, consider if you have a $2 million pre-tax IRA and a single heir with an $80,000 income in the 22% bracket. If the heir expects 5% real growth and can withdraw the funds over 11 years, per the [[Stretch_IRA#Level_withdrawals|level withdrawal table]] that would add $228,400 (=$2,000,000 x 11.42%) of taxable income, raising them into the 35% bracket. That would suggest some Roth conversions at 24%, 32%, and even 35% (if the taxes can be paid with other taxable assets) could be beneficial. However, if the IRA were worth $200,000, or the same $2 million IRA were left to ten heirs in similar tax situations in equal amounts, the $22,840 income would not affect their marginal tax rate, and the decision can be made based on the heirs' marginal tax rates today.
Roth conversions where the taxes can be paid from funds outside the conversion are even more beneficial than when the taxes are paid with converted funds, as the analysis [[Traditional_versus_Roth#Maxing_out_your_retirement_accounts|here]] shows. The time to withdrawal can be taken to be the owner's life expectancy plus the ten year distribution period. However, realizing capital gains on taxable assets to raise the funds needed to pay the tax is probably not optimal, as those assets should receive a [[Step-up in basis|step-up in basis]]. A large Roth conversion in your final year of life could be beneficial, as heirs could pay the taxes with taxable assets after they receive the step-up in basis. You may be able to defer payment on large tax bills resulting from Roth conversions or other large amounts of income by using the [[Estimated_tax|safe harbor rules]], especially where you only need to pay withholding and estimated tax payments up to 100% (or 110% for $150k+ Adjusted Gross Income) of last year's total tax owed. Also note that estimated taxes are not owed at all after the date of your death.
===Health Savings Accounts (HSAs)=== {{Main|Health savings account}}
A common tax strategy is to forego withdrawing money from an HSA when medical expenses are incurred, and rather saving the receipts and planning to withdraw at a later date, for the purposes of getting more tax-deferred or tax-free investment growth. There is no time limit for when funds can be withdrawn after an expense is incurred. Upon your death, if you leave the HSA to your spouse, they will be able to withdraw funds from the HSA using your past medical receipts. However, if leaving your HSA to a non-spouse, these accrued medical expenses are lost, and the entire amount of the HSA becomes taxable. Therefore, it always makes sense to make tax-free withdrawals from an HSA (based on past and current medical expenses) ''before'' withdrawing from retirement accounts. See: [[Retirement draw-down priority]]. Even if you do not need the income, it makes sense to withdraw tax-free from an HSA if you think there is a chance your spouse will not for any reason, or if you would leave the HSA to a non-spouse.
If you have withdrawn for all past medical expenses and you do not expect to get enough future medical expenses to exhaust the HSA before you die, it can make sense to make ''taxable'' withdrawals from a HSA, especially if the HSA is large. This is because HSAs inherited by a non-spouse have the entire amount taxable in a single year, whereas withdrawals from a pre-tax retirement account get to be spread over ten years. In this situation, spending down the HSA roughly over your life expectancy is a good strategy.
===Insurance policies===
If you currently have a ''term'' [[life insurance]] policy, make absolutely sure to keep paying the premiums so that the policy will pay out. If there is a chance you will outlive the term of the policy, some term policies have an option to either extend your coverage in one-year increments, and/or to convert the policy to a permanent policy. Either option will cause the premium to increase dramatically, but if you have a short life expectancy, the return-on-investment will likely be very good. Contact your insurance company or agent to inquire about these options.
If you have a ''permanent'' life insurance policy (such as whole life, indexed universal life, etc.), it is probably a good idea to keep paying the premiums too, although there may be more flexibility, especially if the policy has accumulated significant cash value. For all life insurance policies, make sure the beneficiaries are up-to-date and fit into your overall estate plan.
If you are presently working and have a disability insurance policy in force, consult with your physician on whether your medical condition will now, or likely will in the future, qualify you for disability.
===Annuities===
[[Immediate fixed annuity|Single Premium Immediate Annuities (SPIAs)]] are sometimes used by retirees to provide longevity insurance. If you have health problems which are giving you a short life expectancy for your age, buying a SPIA is probably a terrible investment; you would be much better off placing the funds in a low-risk investment and drawing them down. However, if you are older (~85+) and have a good life expectancy for your age, a SPIA can provide large guaranteed payments which can be useful for funding expenses like assisted living, and it will not take many years to break even compared to traditional investments. Carefully weigh the [[Immediate_fixed_annuity#Pros_and_cons|pros and cons]] before purchasing a SPIA, regardless of your age or health.
Other types of annuities are usually over-sold commission-paying financial products and are not appropriate for most investors; they are no more appropriate for those facing the end of life, probably even less-so. Low-cost variable annuities (such as the Fidelity Personal Retirement Annuity<ref name=":0">{{cite web| url=https://www.fidelity.com/annuities/FPRA-variable-annuity/overview| title=Fidelity Personal Retirement Annuity® (FPRA)| publisher=Fidelity Investments| accessdate=Jan 9, 2025}}</ref>) are sometimes appropriate for investors in higher tax brackets seeking additional tax-deferred space for [[Tax-efficient fund placement|tax-inefficient]] investments. However, the [[Non-deductible_traditional_IRA#Comparison_between_non-deductible_tIRA_and_taxable_accounts|benefit]] depends on a long time horizon, and so probably does not outweigh the additional complexity for investors facing the end of life.
===Social Security===
[[Social Security]] retirement benefits are actuarially neutral for someone with average life expectancy with respect to the age to file, which can be anytime between age 62 and 70. For those with average or better life expectancy, the standard strategy is to wait until age 70 to file if single, or for married couples for the higher-earning spouse to file at 70 and the lower-earning spouse at 62. For someone with below-average life expectancy, it is usually better to file as soon as possible, but there may be more complex strategies when coordinating with a spouse. See also: [https://opensocialsecurity.com/ Open Social Security] for a calculator that can account for life expectancy.
Social Security disability benefits may be available if you are no longer able to work.
Social Security survivor benefits may be available to your spouse and dependent-age children. Look into whether your surviving family will be eligible for survivor benefits, and ensure the income is included in their financial plan.
===Physical assets and personal property===
If you have any valuable physical assets (such as cash, vehicles, precious metals, jewelry, art, collectibles, etc.), locate them and prepare a list, including a description, location, and approximate value. Typically, you will designate who will inherit these assets in a [[Estate_planning#Wills|will]]. Similarly, you can designate who will inherit other personal property in the will, such as items with sentimental value.
==Debts==
Most debts are not discharged at death, and any non-dischargeable debts still existing after your death will need to be paid off by your estate. For each debt, decide whether it makes sense to pay it off now or to leave it:
*As a general rule, avoid selling appreciated [[Taxable_account|taxable assets]] (for example, investments, real estate) to pay off a debt, because of the [[Step-up in basis|step-up in basis]]. *Small "nuisance" debts should be paid off in the name of simplicity. *High-interest debts should also be paid off quickly regardless of your life expectancy, but it is especially important when facing serious medical issues and/or the end of your life, because it will take some time for a POA to take over your finances, and for an executor to be appointed and take over your estate, and interest will continue to accrue at a high rate during this time. *Low-interest debts that made sense to keep before should probably continue to be kept, especially if they are secured by property that has appreciated (for example, a low-interest mortgage on an appreciated house, or a margin loan on investments). *If you leave any debts for your estate, make sure your estate has enough liquid assets to pay them off. This is especially important for unsecured (that is, no collateral) debts. *If you have any undocumented or poorly documented loans, for example, personal loans to family or friends, either document these debts or pay them off. *Federal student loans, including Parent PLUS loans, ''are'' discharged at death, so avoid paying on these loans as much as possible. *If the net value of your estate is negative (that is, you expect your debts to exceed your assets at death), it is probably also a good idea to not pay any more on debts than necessary.
